choices.text: Lateral popliteal nerve

questions.text: Nerve biopsy in leprosy is usually taken from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sural nerve

 

Option D.

 

NERVE BIOPSY

 

  • Leprosy affects relatively superficial nerves – ulnar, CPN, sural nerve but biopsy is not taken from CPN or ulnar nerve as it can cause motor weakness.
  • Biopsy of a peripheral nerve is a valuable tool for the diagnosis of leprosy when the clinical examination and the skin biopsy report are inconclusive.
  • A biopsy is of immense value in confirming a diagnosis in cases of pure neural leprosy.
  • The ideal nerve is the sural nerve, although a sensory branch of the radial cutaneous nerve can be biopsied.
  • In more than 90% of patients, the sural nerve is largely a sensory nerve; in the remaining 10% of patients, it contains only a few motor fibers.
  • The sural nerve is commonly involved in leprosy and is easily accessible for surgery.
  • Following the biopsy, a formalin-fixed nerve segment is dissected in 2–4 pieces that are arranged transversely and longitudinally in a paraffin block to cut sections of 3–4 mm thickness.
  • Histopathological characteristic features of nerve lesions in leprosy include a predominance of macrophage infiltrates, a good number of plasma cells, and scanty, mostly dispersed, lymphocytes.
  • The further a lesion is toward the polar lepromatous end of the spectrum, the fewer the lymphocytes.
  • A reduction in nerve fiber density and a proportionate increase in intraneural collagen may be seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is not commonly biopsied in cases of leprosy. While it is a major nerve in the forearm and hand, it is not typically involved in leprosy-related neuropathies.

 

Option B. Median nerve. The median nerve is also not commonly biopsied in leprosy cases. Leprosy typically affects peripheral nerves more distally in the limbs, and the median nerve may not be as frequently involved.

 

Option C. Lateral popliteal nerve. The lateral popliteal nerve is commonly affected by leprosy neuropathy. It supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and the web space between the first and second toes. Biopsy of this nerve is often undertaken in cases of suspected leprosy neuropathy to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The sural nerve, located in the lower leg, is a common site for nerve biopsy in cases of leprosy.
  • It is a sensory nerve that provides innervation to the lateral aspect of the foot and ankle.
  • Biopsy of the sural nerve can provide valuable diagnostic information in cases of suspected leprosy neuropathy.

choices.text: Superficial radial nerve

questions.text: In Carpal tunnel syndrome, nerve compressed is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

Option A:

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME (CTS)

 

  • It is entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • The primary factor contributing to the onset of CTS is the elevated pressure within the carpal tunnel. 
  • The typical initial signs of CTS include pain, numbness, and paresthesias, which affect the first 3 digits and the lateral half of the fourth digit. 
  • Symptoms of CTS can exhibit variability, with pain manifesting at the wrist, involving the entire hand, and potentially radiating up the forearm or extending beyond the elbow. 
  • Pain associated with CTS does not typically extend to the neck.
  • As the condition advances, individuals may experience hand weakness, diminished fine motor coordination, clumsiness, and eventual atrophy of the thenar muscles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is compressed in the cubital tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C: Superficial radial nerve. Cheiralgia paresthetic is compression of the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm.

 

Option D: Musculocutaneous nerve. Isolated musculocutaneous nerve syndromes are relatively uncommon. Most significant entrapment occurs within the coracobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis weakness and atrophy with accompanying loss of sensation in the lateral forearm. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In carpal tunnel syndrome, the median nerve is compressed under the flexor retinaculum at the wrist.

choices.text: Evidence of atherosclerosis
Exercise-induced calf claudication
Abnormal relation between popliteal artery and lateral head of gastrocnemius
Decreased ankle pulses with ankle extension

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in popliteal entrapment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exercise-induced calf claudication

 

Option B.

 

POPLITEAL ARTERY ENTRAPMENT SYNDROME

 

  • Congenital abnormality between medial head of gastrocnemius and popliteal artery.
  • This embryologically developmental anomaly results mainly due to an aberrant relationship of the popliteal artery with the surrounding popliteal fossa myofascial structures.
  • Decreased ankle pulses on ankle flexion.
  • The hallmark of this disease is a vascular compromise within the popliteal fossa resulting in an insidious, progressive course of exercise intolerance and calf pain with light exercise, relieved by rest (claudication).
  • Patients often report limb swelling as primary complaint.
  • Foot numbness and paresthesias also common.
  • Tingling sensation of toes following vigorous exercise.
  • Limbs can occasionally be asymptomatic.
  • Physical examination:
    • Diminished pulses with active foot plantar flexion or passive foot dorsiflexion
    • Coolness of posterior calf and paresthesias may also be present
    • Can easily be confused with posterior compartment syndrome
  • Treatment: Release of muscular origin of medial head of gastrocnemius.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Evidence of atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arteries, leading to narrowing and reduced blood flow. While atherosclerosis itself might not be the primary cause, popliteal entrapment syndrome can occur in individuals with existing atherosclerosis, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option C. Abnormal relation between popliteal artery and lateral head of gastrocnemius: This anatomical abnormality is indeed common in people with popliteal entrapment syndrome. However, it is not the symptom that defines the condition. It is the abnormal relation between the popliteal artery and the medial head of gastrocnemius and not with the lateral head.

 

Option D. Decreased ankle pulses with ankle extension: This finding can be present in severe cases of popliteal entrapment syndrome, but it is not a consistent symptom. The primary symptom remains the calf pain and cramping during exercise. Decreased ankle pulses might be more indicative of a more advanced stage of the condition or other underlying vascular problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calf claudication is a symptom typically associated with peripheral artery disease (PAD), where there's a generalized narrowing of the arteries in the legs due to atherosclerosis.
  • While PAD can coexist with popliteal entrapment syndrome, the classic symptom of popliteal entrapment is pain or cramping in the calf and foot that occurs specifically during exercise and improves with rest.
  • This is different from claudication, which can occur even at rest in severe PAD cases.

questions.text: In Guyon’s canal, which nerve is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

Option B:

 

GUYON’S CANAL

 

  • Guyon canal syndrome is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy that involves injury to the distal portion of the ulnar nerve as it travels through a narrow anatomic corridor at the wrist. 
  • The ulnar nerve reaches the hand via Guyon canal to provide motor and sensory innervation to the digits.
  • The anatomic boundaries of Guyon canal are:
    • Volar carpal ligament: roof
    • Transverse carpal ligament: floor
    • Pisiform, Pisohamate ligament, abductor digiti minimi: ulnar boundary
    • The hook of hamate: radial boundary
  • Etiology:
    • Ganglion Cyst
    • The hook of hamate Fracture/Displacement
    • Tumors (e.g., lipoma)
    • Repetitive trauma (e.g., Cyclist's handlebar external compression)
    • Aberrant Muscle (e.g., abductor digiti minimi) or excess fat tissue within the canal
    • Ulnar artery thrombosis or aneurysm
  • Clinical features:
    • Signs and symptoms can be purely motor, purely sensory, or mixed depending on the zone of the distal ulnar nerve lesion.
    • Motor complaints may include weakness/paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand innervated by the ulnar nerve, which may present as a weakening of the handgrip and clawing of the 4th-5th digits.
    • Hypothenar atrophy may be present in more advanced cases.
    • Sparing of the dorsal surface of ulnar dermatome (dorsal medial hand and two fingers) points to Guyon canal syndrome. This occurs because this region is innervated by the dorsal ulnar cutaneous branch which comes off about 5 cm proximal to the Guyon canal entrance. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Median nerve. The median nerve is compressed in the flexor retinaculum of the wrist. This leads to carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C: Radial nerve. The radial nerve is compressed most commonly in the proximal forearm.

 

Option D: Musculocutaneous nerve. It is entrapped commonly within the corachobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis muscle weakness and atrophy, and loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In Guyon’s canal, the ulnar nerve is most commonly compressed as the nerve passes through the canal to innervate the hand.

choices.text: Superficial radial nerve

questions.text: Cheiralgia paresthetica involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial radial nerve

 

Option C:

 

CHEIRALGIA PARESTHETICA

 

  • Cheiralgia paresthetica is a compression neuropathy of the superficial radial nerve in the forearm.
  • It is also commonly known as Wartenburg syndrome and superficial radial nerve palsy. 
  • The superficial radial nerve is purely sensory and does not have any motor component. 
  • The condition presents with symptoms such as pain and burning located on the dorsal and radial side of the hand.
  • Often it is aggravated by activities such as pronation, pinching, and gripping.
  • Due to the superficial location of the terminal branches, the nerve is at risk for local trauma. 
  • Tight wrist watches and tight handcuff can compress the nerve over the lateral wrist. 
  • Its superficial location predisposes it to injury from penetrating wounds. 
  • It is also at risk for compression caused by distal radius fracture fragments of by soft tissue masses like lipomas or ganglion cysts. 
  • Steroid injections into the adjacent tendon sheath for de Quervain's tenosynovitis can damage the nerve itself and can cause subdermal atrophy predisposing the nerve to injury.
  • The nerve is more vulnerable where it passes from deep to superficial. 
  • Compression may occur from fascial bands between the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus and fascial rings of the dorsal brachioradialis.
  • Repetitive supination and pronation can trap the nerve between the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus. 
  • The patient presents with pain, tingling, paresthesias over the dorsolateral aspect of the hand, wrist, and fingers. 
  • The symptoms may extend from the dorsal radial forearm into the thumb, index, and long fingers. 
  • The patient often describes the pain as burning or shooting pain, as opposed to dull and achy pain. 
  • The symptoms may be acute, intermittent, or chronic, which is related to the cause of irritation.
  • Other symptoms can include tenderness, allodynia, dysesthesias, hypoesthesias.
  • Specific motions, including flexion and ulnar deviation of the wrist exacerbate the symptoms and can be magnified with pinching and gripping through this motion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve can be entrapped in the wrist or elbow. Its compression at the wrist is called Guyon Canal Syndrome while that at the elbow is called Cubital Tunnel Syndrome.

 

Option B: Median nerve. The median nerve is compressed in the flexor retinaculum of the wrist. This leads to carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D: Musculocutaneous nerve. It is entrapped commonly within the corachobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis muscle weakness and atrophy, and loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cheiralgia paresthetica involves entrapment of the superficial radial nerve in the forearm.
  • Other entrapment syndromes involving the peripheral nerves are:

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Common digital nerve

questions.text: Entrapment neuropathies commonly affect the following nerves except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral nerve

 

Option B:

 

ENTRAPMENT NEUROPATHY

 

  • The femoral nerve is a major nerve that supplies motor and sensory innervation to the muscles and skin of the anterior thigh and parts of the leg.
  • While entrapment neuropathies can affect any nerve in the body, certain nerves are more prone to compression due to their anatomical locations or the structures they pass through.
  • The femoral nerve typically courses through the pelvis and then descends into the thigh, passing beneath the inguinal ligament.
  • Unlike some other nerves, such as the median nerve in the carpal tunnel or the ulnar nerve at the elbow, the femoral nerve does not pass through narrow anatomical tunnels or spaces prone to compression.
  • However, it's essential to note that while entrapment neuropathies of the femoral nerve may be less common compared to other nerves, they can still occur. For example, the femoral nerve can be compressed or injured due to trauma, pelvic masses, or post-surgical complications.
  • Additionally, certain conditions like femoral neuropathy or iliopsoas muscle impingement can lead to compression of the femoral nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The femoral nerve is least prone to entrapment neuropathy because it does not pass through a closed tunnel like some nerves.
  • The other nerves and the related entrapment syndromes include:

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: While doing sudden hyperflexion of thigh over abdomen (McRoberts procedure) during childbirth, which of the following nerve is commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

Option D)

 

McROBERTS PROCEDURE

 

  • McRoberts maneuver to deliver babies with shoulder dystocia can cause compression of femoral nerve by overlying inguinal ligament. 
  • Occasionally, lateral femoral cutaneous nerve may get damaged.
  • Hyperflexion of the hip resulting in compression of the femoral nerve or the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve beneath the inguinal ligament can lead to maternal lower extremity neuropathies. 
  • Clinically, femoral neuropathy presents with ipsilateral weakness in the quadriceps, causing decreased hip flexion and knee extension. 
  • Adduction, however, is spared because it is mediated by the obturator rather than the femoral nerve. 
  • Injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve presents as ipsilateral paresthesias, sensory loss, and, potentially, pain radiating down the lateral thigh. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common peroneal nerve: The common peroneal nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the muscles of the lower leg and foot, as well as providing sensory innervation to parts of the leg and foot. It does not get directly affected during the McRoberts procedure. However, if there were complications during childbirth, such as prolonged pressure on the lower leg or foot, there could be indirect effects on the common peroneal nerve. For example, prolonged pressure or stretching of the leg during childbirth could potentially result in nerve compression or injury. However, compared to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, the common peroneal nerve is less directly involved in the maneuver described in the question.

 

Option B. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the muscles of the medial thigh and the skin of the inner thigh. While the obturator nerve does pass through the pelvic region and could theoretically be affected by pressure or stretching during the McRoberts procedure, it is less likely to be directly involved compared to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The McRoberts procedure primarily involves hyperflexion of the thigh over the abdomen, which puts more direct pressure on nerves in the anterior and lateral aspects of the thigh rather than those in the medial aspect.

 

Option C. Lumbosacral trunk: The lumbosacral trunk is formed by the merging of the fifth lumbar nerve root and the first sacral nerve root. It contributes to the formation of the sciatic nerve and does not directly supply the muscles or skin of the thigh. Therefore, it is unlikely to be directly affected during the McRoberts procedure. This nerve primarily plays a role in the lower back and pelvic region rather than the thigh itself.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • One of the complications of the McRoberts procedure is the compression of femoral nerve due to its compression beneath the inguinal canal. 
  • Among the given options, the lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh is affected by compression beneath the inguinal ligament.

choices.text: Compression of communication between medial and lateral plantar nerves
Exaggeration of longitudinal arches
Injury to deltoid ligament
Shortening of plantar aponeurosis

questions.text: Commonest cause for neuralgic pain in foot is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of communication between medial and lateral plantar nerves

 

Option A:

 

NEURALGIC PAIN IN FOOT

 

  • Most common cause of pain, burning, paresthesia or numbness in the sole of the foot is compression of communication between medial and lateral plantar nerve.
  • The nerve branches are pinched between bone, ligaments, and other connective tissues, causing pain.
  • The pain worsens when ankle motion and certain shoes or activities such as running put additional pressure on the pinched nerves.
  • Symptoms of medial and lateral plantar nerve entrapment include almost constant pain, whether walking or sitting.
  • Just standing is often difficult.
  • The pain is often chronic, difficult to treat, and aggravated by high-impact activities such as running.
  • Burning, numbness, and tingling, which often occur when nerves are compressed, usually do not occur in medial and lateral plantar nerve entrapment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Exaggeration of longitudinal arches. Exaggeration of the longitudinal arches of the foot, also known as pes planus or flat feet, can lead to various foot problems, including pain and discomfort. However, it is not related to the neuralgic pain in the foot. Flat feet may cause strain on various structures of the foot, but neuralgic pain is more commonly associated with nerve-related issues rather than structural abnormalities of the foot arches.

 

Option C: Injury to deltoid ligament. The deltoid ligament is a strong ligament on the medial aspect of the ankle that provides stability to the joint. Injury to this ligament, known as deltoid ligament sprain, can lead to medial ankle pain and instability. However, neuralgic pain in the foot is not typically associated with injury to the deltoid ligament.

 

Option D: Shortening of plantar aponeurosis. The plantar aponeurosis, also known as the plantar fascia, is a thick band of connective tissue that supports the arch of the foot. Shortening or tightening of the plantar aponeurosis can lead to conditions like plantar fasciitis, which commonly causes heel pain rather than neuralgic pain throughout the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The commonest cause of neuralgic pain in the foot is the compression of the communication between medial lateral plantar nerves.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Posterior tibiaI nerve
Common peroneal nerve

questions.text: Tarsal tunnel syndrome involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial nerve

 

Option B:

 

TARSAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is characterized by the compression or entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve when it passes through the tarsal tunnel.
  • Posterior Tibial Nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the posterior compartment of the lower leg and the sole of the foot.
  • Most common cause: Idiopathic > Osteoarthritis > Rheumatoid Arthritis > Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • Features:
    • Pain and Tingling sensation
    • Burning pain along the plantar aspect of foot
    • Weakness and wasting of the muscles supplied
    • Positive Tinel’s sign
    • Symptoms increased on activity

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh. Meralgia paresthetica is a clinical condition that involves pain and dysesthesia in the anterolateral thigh associated with compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. 

 

Option C: Common peroneal nerve. This nerve is injured by trauma at the neck of the fibula most commonly, leading to classic foot drop deformity.

 

Option D: Sciatic nerve. Sciatic nerve is compressed in herniated or bulged lumbar intervertebral disc, causing symptoms commonly called as sciatica.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tarsal tunnel syndrome involves compression of the posterior tibial nerve beneath the flexor retinaculum as it passes behind the medial malleolus.
  • It may arise from a space-occupying lesion within the tarsal tunnel or distally against medial or lateral plantar nerves.

questions.text: Most common cause of tarsal tunnel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

 

Option A:

 

TARSAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is compressive neuropathy of posterior tibial nerve as it passes behind the medial malleolus.
  • It may arise from space occupying lesion within the tarsal tunnel (e.g. a ganglion, synovial cyst or lipoma) or distally against one of the two terminal branches: the medial or lateral plantar nerve.
  • Most common cause: Idiopathic > Osteoarthritis > Rheumatoid Arthritis > Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, the most common cause of tarsal tunnel syndrome is osteoarthritis.
  • The other causes include rheumatoid arthritis > ankylosing spondylitis.

choices.text: Tarsal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: In a patient with a history of burning pain localized to the plantar aspect of the foot, the differential diagnosis must include:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tarsal tunnel syndrome

 

Option C:

 

TARSAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is characterized by the compression or entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve when it passes through the tarsal tunnel.
  • Posterior Tibial Nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the posterior compartment of the lower leg and the sole of the foot.
  • Most common cause: Idiopathic > Osteoarthritis > Rheumatoid Arthritis > Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • Features:
    • Pain and Tingling sensation
    • Burning pain along the plantar aspect of foot
    • Weakness and wasting of the muscles supplied
    • Positive Tinel’s sign
    • Symptoms increased on activity

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Peripheral vascular disease. Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) includes peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and venous disease. PAD is a chronic progressive atherosclerotic disease leading to partial or total peripheral vascular occlusion. PAD typically affects the abdominal aorta, iliac arteries, lower limbs, and occasionally the upper extremities. There is atypical pain characterized by pain unrelated to physical activity, that occurs both at rest and exertion, and lasting longer than 10 minutes after exercise cessation. Intermittent claudication is the most classic symptom of PAD, characterized by an exercise-induced cramping sensation with associated fatigue, weakness, and or pressure. Symptoms are exacerbated by leg elevation and relieved by placing the limb in a dependent position. Paresthesias, lower extremity weakness, stiffness, and cool extremities may also be present.

 

Option B: Tarsal coalition. Tarsal coalition is the complete or partial union between two or more bones in the midfoot and hindfoot. It is a developmental fusion and not that acquired secondary to rheumatoid arthritis, trauma or post-surgery. It can present as osseous (synostosis), fibrous (syndesmosis), or cartilaginous (synchondrosis) connections between the tarsal bones. Adolescents present with the insidious onset of hind foot pain with or without recurrent ankle sprains. Some complain of stiffness in the hind foot. The pain is usually described as coming from the lateral side of the hind foot and ankle. A twisting injury may stretch, tear, or disrupt the coalition, causing the coalition to become painful.

 

Option D: Plantar fibromatosis. Plantar fibromatosis is a benign fibroblastic, connective tissue proliferative disorder of the superficial plantar aponeurosis of the foot. Onset is slow, and patients usually present after the disease becomes locally aggressive, causing pain and swelling in the medial non-weight bearing plantar surface of the feet. The classic presentation is that of a slow-growing, painless nodule in the medial or central plantar aponeurosis of the foot. Smaller nodules can present as local pressure points. Locally invasive nodules can lead to pain and swelling, and trouble with ambulation. Patients commonly present after experiencing increased pain in the plantar surface of the foot after long walks. Activities such as long walks, prolonged standing, and walking barefoot can exacerbate the symptoms.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Three most common causes of pain in plantar aspect of foot are plantar fasciitis, tarsal tunnel syndrome, and posterior tibial tendinopathy.
  • Burning pain is characteristic of neural pain.
  • Hence, tarsal tunnel syndrome is preferred here.

questions.text: Identify the given X-ray abnormality.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical Rib

 

Option B:

 

CERVICAL RIB

 

  • Cervical ribs are accessory ribs arising from the seventh cervical vertebra.
  • It is a congenital overdevelopment of the transverse process of a 7th cervical spine vertebra.
  • They occur in ~0.5% of the population, are usually bilateral, but often asymmetric, and are more common in females.
  • Although cervical ribs are usually asymptomatic, they are the most important anatomic rib variant clinically, because they can cause thoracic outlet syndrome by compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian artery/vein.
  • It is attached posteriorly to the first rib by a fibrous band near in the insertion of the anterior scalene muscle. 
  • Unilateral cervical ribs are found more frequently on the left side than the right side.
  • Unilateral cervical ribs occur more frequently than bilateral cervical ribs.
  • There is no physiological function of a cervical rib.
  • In the majority of cases, cervical ribs are discovered incidentally on a chest or cervical X-ray.
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Costochondritis. Costochondritis is a common, usually self-limiting, painful inflammation of one or multiple costochondral junctions and/or the costosternal articulation. There is usually absence of swelling, and chest wall palpation usually reproduces the pain. 

 

 

 

Option C: 2nd – 3rd rib fracture. 1st-3rd rib fractures are associated with brachial plexus or subclavian vessel injuries. These ribs are most commonly injured in high-energy traumas. Plain radiograph may miss up to 50% of rib fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows the cervical rib arising from the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.

questions.text:
Nerve Roots of Long Thoracic Nerve of Bell:

 

  1. C5
  2. C6
  3. C7
  4. C8
  5. T1
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Option B:

 

LONG THORACIC NERVE OF BELL

 

  • Long Thoracic nerve, also referred to as the external respiratory nerve of Bell or posterior thoracic nerve, arises from the upper portion of the superior trunk of the brachial plexus and typically receives contributions from cervical nerve roots C5, C6, and C7.
  • It is responsible for the innervation of the serratus anterior muscle.
  • The long thoracic nerve descends posteriorly to the roots of the brachial plexus and anteriorly to the scalenus posterior muscle, and courses along the chest wall in the mid-axillary line to lie on the superficial surface of the serratus anterior muscle.
  • Due to its long, relatively superficial course, the long thoracic nerve is susceptible to damage during certain surgical procedures or through direct trauma or stretch.
  • When the long thoracic nerve is injured, a phenomenon known as winging of the scapula results.
  • The long thoracic nerve is the motor nerve to the serratus anterior muscle, which functions to pull the scapula forward around the thorax, allowing for anteversion of the arm, and to lift the ribs, assisting in respiration.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The nerve root of long thoracic nerve of bell is C5, C6, C7.

choices.text: Radial nerve injury

questions.text: Positive Adson’s test is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracic outlet syndrome

 

Option A:

 

ADSON’S TEST

 

  • Thoracic outlet is a space between the first rib clavicle and the scalene muscle.
  • Compression of neurovascular bundle consisting of subclavian and axillary blood vessels and brachial plexus at the thoracic outlet is included in thoracic outlet syndrome.
  • Causes:
    • Narrowing of the space either due to hypertrophy of the existing muscles or due to any other cause like congenital, trauma, etc.
  1. Cervical rib syndrome
  2. Heavy exercises or manual Laborer’s
  3. Malunion/non-union of fracture clavicle

 

 

(change image)

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Vascular: Numbness of the upper limb during overhead exercises, cold cyanosis, pallor and Raynaud’s phenomenon that recovers on rest.
    • Neurogenic: Commonly involves C8 and T1 nerve roots (T1 > C8). There is paresthesia along the medial aspect of the arm, hand and little fingers, and there is weakness of the hand.
  • Tests
    • Adson’s test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The test can be performed with the patient in either sitting or standing with their elbow in full extension. The arm of the patient is abducted to 30 at the shoulder and maximally extended. The radial pulse is palpated. The patient then extends the neck and turns the head toward the symptomatic shoulder and is asked to take a deep breath and hold it. The quality of the radial pulse is evaluated in comparison to the pulse taken while the arm is resting at the patient's side. The test is positive if there is a decrease, or disappearance, of the radial pulse.

 

 

  • Wright’s test: Wright test or hyper abduction test is a provocative test  for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The test is performed in the sitting and then in the supine position. The test is performed in 2 steps. In the first step, the head is held forward, while the arm is passively brought into abduction and external rotation to 90 without tilting the head. The elbow is flexed till 45. The arm is then held for 1 min and the radial pulse is measured. In the second step, the test is repeated with extremity in hyperabduction. The test is positive if there is a decrease in the radial pulse and/or reproduction of the symptoms.

 

 

  • Roos test: This test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS). It is also known as the “elevated arm stress test” or "EAST". The patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position with the shoulders and elbows in the frontal plane of the chest. The patient is asked to open and close the hands slowly over 3-minute. Results are normal if there is only forearm muscle fatigue and minimal distress. If TOS is present, there will be gradual increase in pain at neck and shoulder, progressing down the arm, and paraesthesia in forearm and fingers. In case of arterial compression, there will be arm pallor with elevation, and reactive hyperemia when limb is lowered. In case of venous compression, there will be cyanosis and swelling. Inability to complete test, and patient drops arms in marked distress is recognized as reproduction of usual symptoms.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Buerger disease. Buerger's disease or thromboangitis is an inflammatory non atherosclerotic, inflammatory disease that affects small and medium arteries and veins of the upper and lower limbs and more common in tobacco use patients, mostly men than women < 45 years of age. To test the blood flow in this disease, the Allen’s test is done.

 

Option C: Varicose veins. For clinical examination of the varicose veins, Trendelenburg test, Schwartz test, and Perthe’s test are done.

 

Option D: Radial nerve injury. Radial nerve palsy is tested by wrist drop test, supination test, and thumb extension test.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Adson’s test is positive in thoracic outlet syndrome.
  • It is a provocative test.

choices.text: Flexion at hip and knee
Flexion at hip, extension at knee
Extension at hip, flexion at knee
Extension at hip and knee

questions.text: Iliotibial band contracture in patients of poliomyelitis will lead to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion at hip and knee

 

Option A:

 

ILIOTIBIAL BAND CONTRACTURE

 

  • Contracture of iliotibial tract in polio results in these classical deformities:
  1. Lumbar scoliosis
  2. Pelvic obliquity
  3. Hip flexion and abduction
  4. External rotation of femur
  5. Triple deformity of knee
  6. Flexion and valgus of knee
  7. Posterior and lateral subluxation of tibia
  8. External rotation of tibia
  9. Foot in equinus
  10. Shortening

 

  • Ober’s test demonstrates iliotibial tract contracture (as in polio).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the iliotibial band contracture in patients with polio, there is flexion deformity of the hip and knee seen.

choices.text: Lumbar plexus injury

questions.text: The most common cause of Sciatic nerve palsy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fractures

 

Option A:

 

SCIATIC NERVE PALSY

 

  • The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, arising from the sacral plexus (L4-S3) and traveling down the posterior thigh into the leg.
  • Sciatic nerve palsy refers to dysfunction or damage to this nerve, which can result in symptoms such as pain, numbness, weakness, or loss of function in the lower limb.
  • Fractures, particularly those involving the pelvis or the proximal femur, can commonly lead to sciatic nerve palsy.
  • When a fracture occurs in the pelvis or the upper part of the femur, there is a risk of direct trauma to the sciatic nerve or compression of the nerve due to displacement of fractured bone fragments.
  • In cases of pelvic fractures, the sciatic nerve can be stretched, compressed, or even directly injured due to the trauma.
  • Similarly, fractures of the proximal femur, such as femoral neck fractures or intertrochanteric fractures, can also lead to compression or injury of the sciatic nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Injections. Injections can occasionally cause sciatic nerve injury, it is not as common as fractures. Sciatic nerve injury from injections typically occurs due to inadvertent needle trauma during procedures such as intramuscular injections, nerve blocks, or other medical interventions. In cases where injections lead to sciatic nerve injury, symptoms may include pain, numbness, or weakness in the distribution of the sciatic nerve.

 

Option C: Idiopathic. Idiopathic causes refer to those cases where the exact cause of sciatic nerve palsy is unknown, but fractures are more commonly identified as the cause. While idiopathic cases do exist, they are relatively less common compared to cases where a specific cause, such as fractures or other identifiable injuries, is present. Idiopathic sciatic nerve palsy may occur due to various factors, including spontaneous nerve inflammation or compression, but these cases often require thorough investigation to rule out other potential causes.

 

Option D: Lumbar plexus injury. The lumbar plexus is a network of nerves in the lumbar region of the spine, giving rise to several major nerves, including the sciatic nerve. Injury to the lumbar plexus can potentially lead to sciatic nerve dysfunction. However, lumbar plexus injury causing sciatic nerve palsy is less common compared to direct trauma or compression of the sciatic nerve itself, such as in cases of fractures. Lumbar plexus injury may occur due to various causes, including trauma, surgery, or compression by tumors, but it is not typically the most common cause of sciatic nerve palsy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of sciatic nerve palsy is the presence of fracture usually in the pelvis or proximal femur.

choices.text: Long thoracic nerve
Nerve to latissimus dorsi
Nerve to latissimus dorsi
Nerve to rhomboid

questions.text: Winging of scapula is due to palsy of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Long thoracic nerve

 

Option A:

 

WINGING OF SCAPULA

 

  • In a patient with a winged scapula, the medial or lateral aspect of the scapula appears to be protruding from the back. 

 

 

Vertebral border and inferior angle of scapula is prominent due to Serratus Anterior paralysis
 

  • The most common etiology of a winged scapula is damage or impaired innervation to the serratus anterior muscle.
  • The nerve that innervates this muscle is the long thoracic nerve.
  • This nerve damage leads to malfunction of the serratus anterior muscle.
  • Some patients may also complain of an inability to raise the affected arm above their head.
  • This dysfunction results in the medial border of the scapula giving a winged-like appearance.
  • The impingement or damage of this nerve leads to the winged appearance because the serratus anterior muscle attaches to the medial aspect of the scapula and holds it against the posterior rib cage.
  • Less commonly, the scapula can wing laterally due to damage to the trapezius or rhomboid muscles, which are innervated by the spinal accessory nerves and dorsal scapular nerve, respectively.
  • The scapula will move laterally due to unopposed muscle strength attributed to the trapezium or rhomboid paralysis or weakness; this occurs because the function of the trapezius muscle is to elevate, retract and rotate the scapula.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Nerve to lattisimus dorsi. The injury of this nerve is characterized by paresis or paralysis of the latissimus dorsi muscle. The patients are unable to perform full extension, rotation, and adduction of the arm. In addition, the thoracodorsal nerve is often used as a nerve graft when the long thoracic nerve (C5-C7) is injured.

 

Option C: Spinal accessory nerve. The most common and primary complaint of spinal accessory nerve injury is pain and weakness, mostly involving the shoulder. Radiation of pain is to the upper back, neck, and ipsilateral arm. Pain is exacerbated with weight on the injured shoulder without being supported. The traction and straining of the muscles, such as rhomboids and levator scapulae that work to compensate for the nerve injury, could lead to more pain and decreased strength on the injured side. The combination of the pain and decreased strength would limit the range of motion of the involved shoulder.

 

Option D: Nerve to rhomboid. Compression of the dorsal scapular nerve (DSN) is a condition in which the dorsal scapular nerve entraps in the middle scalene muscle causing pain and stiffness in the shoulder girdle and limited end range motion, along with winging of scapula. The most common source of DSN entrapment is a hypertrophied middle scalene muscle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Winging of scapula is due to the damage to the long thoracic nerve that supplied the serratus anterior muscle, which leads to protrusion of the medial border of the scapula while moving the shoulder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with weakness, pain and fatigue in both lower limbs. He gives history of both limb paralysis 20 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Post-polio syndrome

 

Option C:

 

POST POLIO SYNDROME

 

  • Post-polio syndrome (PPS, or post-poliomyelitis syndrome or post-polio sequelae) affects 25–50% of people who have previously contracted poliomyelitis.
  • Typically, the symptoms appear 15–30 years after recovery from the original paralytic attack, at an age of 35–60.
  • Symptoms include acute or increased muscular weakness, pain in the muscles, and fatigue. The same symptoms may also occur years after a non-paralytic polio (NPP) infection.
  • The precise mechanism that causes PPS is unknown.
  • It shares many features with the post-viral chronic fatigue syndrome, but unlike that disorder it tends to be progressive, and as such can cause a tangible loss of muscle strength.
  • Treatment is primarily limited to adequate rest, conservation of available energy, and supportive measures, such as leg braces and energy-saving devices such as powered wheelchairs, analgesia (pain relief) and sleep aids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Polymyositis. Polymyositis, a relatively uncommon autoimmune disorder that develops due to abnormal activation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CD8 cells) and macrophages against muscular antigens that result in rhabdomyolysis and ultimately presents as a proximal myopathy. Polymyositis is characterized by symmetrical proximal muscle weakness due to the involvement of endomysial layers of skeletal muscles versus dermatomyositis, which involves the perimysial layers of muscles along with dermatological presentations. Polymyositis develops over the months. Polymyositis rarely presents in childhood and usually affects people above the age of 20 years. The hallmark of polymyositis is a progressive disease with symmetric involvement of shoulder and pelvic girdle muscles and neck flexors. Hip extensors can be involved making it difficult for patients to climb stairs. Patients may complain of the inability of overhead abduction or to get up from the seated position. Disease progression to distal muscles can result in abnormal fine movements such as writing and playing musical instruments. Constitutional symptoms include low-grade fever, anorexia, arthralgia, and weight loss. Polymyositis can cause interstitial lung disease (ILD), especially in anti-Jo-1 positive patients, presenting as shortness of breath and dry cough. Other presenting complaints are chest tightness and exertional dyspnea due to restrictive cardiomyopathy, constipation, or bloating due to gastrointestinal involvement and tightening and discoloration of fingers due to Raynaud phenomenon.

 

Option B: Muscular dystrophy. It is a hereditary disorder that leads to progressive and generalized disease of the muscle due to inadequate or missing glycoproteins in the muscle cell plasma membrane. Gracilis, semimembranosus, semitendinosus, and sartorius muscles can be affected. Feet can exhibit an equinovarus deformity. The pelvis can tilt. There may be contractures throughout the body. Spinal deformities may produce lordosis or scoliosis. The eye can exhibit cataracts and bilateral ptosis. Onset usually occurs in the third to fourth decades. There is accelerated deterioration near the age of onset. Parents may present with a concern that their child is not walking as other children their age. There is massive calf muscles and proximal lower limb muscle weakness. The individuals utilize their arms and hands to aid in rising from sitting. Other complaints can involve a history of delayed ambulation, toe walking, calf hypertrophy, and proximal hip girdle muscle instability. There can be asymptomatic elevation of serum creatine kinase, exertion intolerance, dilated cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia, quadriceps myopathy, language delay, and Turner syndrome (Duchenne in X chromosome monozygotic females). Since the inheritance can be X-linked, the majority of patients are male. Scoliosis and sustained alveolar hypoventilation can cause severe problems.

 

Option D: Neuropathy. Neuropathy occurs when nerve damage leads to pain, weakness, numbness or tingling in one or more parts of body. It may be because of disease, infection, injury, medicines, or long-term alcohol abuse. Sometimes, no cause is found. Different typed of neuropathies found are autonomic neuropathy, diabetic neuropathy, peripheral neuropathy, focal or mononeuropathy, and polyneuropathy. Abnormal sensations like numbness, tingling, burning; muscle weakness; pain; loss of movement; problem with digestion, bladder and bowel function, sexual response; sweating, dizziness are some common symptoms associated with neuropathies.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The effect on bilateral lower limbs in the form of fatigue and a history of paralysis 20 years back, are descriptive of post-polio syndrome because the symptoms of poliomyelitis appears 15-20 years after recovery from the initial paralytic episode.
  • There is also characteristic chronic fatigue, post viral infection which is progressive and nature and leads to significant loss of muscle strength.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Female with hypothyroidism, on treatment, complaints of heaviness and tingling in left index and middle fingers. The pain often increases in night and she often has to get up. Which of the following is not a clinical test for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Finkelstein test

 

Option A:

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • The described symptoms in the question are suggestive of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is an entrapment neuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it travels through the wrist's carpal tunnel. 
  • Early symptoms include pain, numbness, and paresthesias; Sensory changes and paresthesia along the nerve distribution in Hand.
  • Symptoms typically present in the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the radial half of the ring finger.
  • Pain also can radiate up the affected arm, shoulder and neck.
  • With further progression, night pain, hand weakness, decreased fine motor coordination, decreased grip strength, clumsiness, reduced wrist mobility and thenar atrophy can occur.
  • The most common causes of carpal tunnel syndrome include genetic predisposition, history of repetitive wrist movements such as repetitive use, typing, or machine work as well as obesity, diabetes, tumor, hypothyroidism, autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, and pregnancy.
  • CTS onset is gradual with tingling or numbness in the median nerve distribution of the hand.
  • Patients may notice aggravation of symptoms with static gripping of objects such as a phone or steering wheel but also at night or early in the morning. 
  • Many patients will report an improvement of symptoms following shaking or flicking of their hand.
  • As the disorder progresses, the feeling of tingling or numbness may become constant and patients may complain of burning pain. 
  • There is weakness and atrophy of muscles of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Special examination tests used for testing the carpal tunnel syndrome are:
    • Phalen’s test: The Phalen's test or ‘reverse prayer’ is performed by fully flexing the wrists by placing dorsal surfaces of both hands for one minute. A positive test is when symptoms (numbness, tingling, pain) are reproduced.

 

 

  • Tinel’s sign: Although a low sensitivity and specificity, the Hoffmann-Tinel sign is another test commonly performed. In this test, the examiner taps immediately over the carpal tunnel to stimulate the median nerve. Like the above tests, a positive test is when symptoms are reproduced.
  • Tourniquet test: A pressure bandage is placed above the wrist to reduce blood flow and thereby cause possible symptoms. The tourniquet test offers a quick way to detect the first signs of carpal tunnel syndrome and receive early treatment. It is important to emphasize that this test is not a definitive diagnosis and if the result is positive, further investigation is necessary.
     
  • The all 3 tests are provocative test i.e.; they tend to reproduce the symptoms of the carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Finkelstein test is done for de Quervain’s tenosynovitis while the other three tests are for carpal tunnel syndrome.

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography

questions.text: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is best diagnosed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clinical examination

 

Option D:

 

THORACIC OUTLET SYNDROME

 

  • Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) refers to a group of disorders that occur when there is compression of neurovascular bundle consisting of subclavian and axillary blood vessels, and brachial plexus at the thoracic outlet area, which is the space between the clavicle and first rib.
  • It can result in various symptoms, including pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the neck, shoulder, arm, and hand.
  • The best method for diagnosing Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is clinical examination, which involves a thorough assessment of the patient's symptoms, medical history, physical examination, and specialized provocative maneuvers.
  • During the clinical examination, the healthcare provider may evaluate for specific signs such as tenderness, weakness, loss of sensation, or changes in pulse strength in the affected limb.
  • Some provocative Tests for TOS used in clinical examination includes:
    • Adson’s test
    • Wright’s test
    • Roos test

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: CT scan. CT scans can be useful in identifying bony abnormalities such as cervical ribs, bony spurs, or other anatomical variations that may contribute to thoracic outlet syndrome. However, CT scans may not always clearly visualize soft tissues or adequately assess vascular compression, which are important considerations in diagnosing TOS. Therefore, while CT scans can be a valuable adjunct to diagnosis, they are not typically considered the primary diagnostic modality for TOS.

 

Option B: MRI. MRI is particularly useful for evaluating soft tissue structures and can help identify abnormalities such as nerve compression, muscle atrophy, or vascular anomalies that may contribute to thoracic outlet syndrome. It can also visualize the spinal cord and nerve roots, which can be helpful in ruling out other potential causes of symptoms. MRI is often considered one of the preferred imaging modalities for diagnosing TOS due to its ability to provide detailed anatomical information without using ionizing radiation.

 

Option C: Digital subtraction angiography. DSA is an invasive imaging technique used to visualize the blood vessels by injecting a contrast dye into the bloodstream and taking X-ray images. It is particularly useful for assessing vascular abnormalities such as arterial compression that may occur in thoracic outlet syndrome. DSA provides dynamic, real-time images of blood flow and can help identify areas of vascular compression or obstruction. While DSA can be valuable in cases where vascular involvement is suspected, it is an invasive procedure associated with potential risks such as allergic reactions to contrast dye, blood vessel injury, or infection. Therefore, it is typically reserved for cases where non-invasive imaging modalities are inconclusive or when intervention (such as angioplasty or surgical decompression) is being considered.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While imaging studies such as CT scan, MRI, and digital subtraction angiography (DSA) can sometimes be useful in supporting the diagnosis and identifying the underlying cause of TOS such as bony abnormalities, vascular compression, or soft tissue abnormalities, they are not typically considered the primary diagnostic tool.
  • These imaging modalities may be ordered in cases where the clinical presentation is ambiguous or to rule out other potential causes of the symptoms.
  • Thus, clinical examination using history of the patient and physical examination tests is the preferred investigation tool for diagnosing thoracic outlet syndrome.

choices.text: Fracture will unite slowly
Fracture will not unite
Fracture will unite normally
Fracture will unite on attaining puberty

questions.text: You have treated the simple and undisplaced fracture of shaft of right tibia in a nine-year-girl with above knee plaster cast. Her parents want to know the prognosis of union of the fractured limb which was affected by poliomyelitis four years ago. What is the best possible advice will you offer to the parents?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture will unite slowly

 

Option A:

 

FRACTURE HEALING AFTER POLIOMYELITIS

 

  • Poliomyelitis can lead to muscle weakness and changes in bone structure, which may impact the healing process of fractures.
  • The weakened musculature and altered biomechanics can affect the stability of the fracture site and potentially slow down the rate of bone formation and remodeling.
  • In the given case scenario, the healing process of the fracture may be prolonged due to the history of poliomyelitis affecting the limb. This implies that despite appropriate treatment and care, the fracture may take a longer time to fully heal and achieve union compared to a child without a history of poliomyelitis.
  • Despite the slower healing process, fractures in children, particularly simple and undisplaced ones, generally have a good prognosis for eventual union.
  • With proper immobilization, supportive care, and possibly physical therapy to address any residual muscle weakness, the fracture is still expected to heal over time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fracture will not unite. This scenario is highly unlikely, especially for a simple and undisplaced fracture in a child. Fractures in children have a good prognosis for healing, even with complicating factors such as a history of poliomyelitis. While healing may be delayed or the process may be more challenging, it is rare for a fracture to completely fail to unite, particularly with appropriate medical management.

 

Option C: Fracture will unite normally. This option suggests that despite the history of poliomyelitis, the fracture will heal in a typical manner without significant delay or complications. While this scenario is possible, it may not fully account for the potential impact of poliomyelitis on the healing process. Fracture healing may indeed occur, but it might be slower than usual due to factors such as compromised muscle strength or altered biomechanics resulting from poliomyelitis.

 

Option D: Fracture will unite on attaining puberty. While fractures may heal at different rates depending on various factors, it is not typical for a fracture to require puberty for union, especially in a child with appropriate treatment and care. Fracture healing usually occurs within weeks to months, rather than years, and puberty is not typically a prerequisite for this process.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the parents must be advised that the fracture will unite slowly, provided the slow healing process due to the history of poliomyelitis.

choices.text: 2 months after the disease
2 years after the disease
6-12 months after the disease
After skeleton maturation

questions.text: In a 3-year-old child with polio paralysis, tendon transfer operation is done at:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 years after the disease

 

Option B:

 

TENDON TRANSFER

 

  • There are done to equalize an unbalanced paralysis or to use the motor power of working muscles for more useful functions.
  • It is not done before 5 years of age as the child has to be manageable enough to be taught proper exercises.
  • As the child is 3 years old, tendon transfer should be done after 2 years (at 5 years of age).
  • The timing of tendon transfer 2 years after the disease allows a longer period of observation and potential spontaneous recovery or stabilization of the muscle function.
  • Delaying the tendon transfer operation until 2 years after the onset of polio paralysis can be chosen for several reasons:
    • Observation Period: By waiting for two years, the child's progress can be closely monitored and assess the signs of spontaneous recovery or stabilization of muscle function. In milder polio paralysis, individuals may experience partial recovery over time without the need for surgical intervention.
    • Skeletal Growth: Performing surgery closer to two years after the onset of polio paralysis allows for consideration of the child's growth and development. This timing may align with the child's skeletal maturity to minimize the risk of growth-related complications and optimize the long-term outcomes of the surgery.
    • Stability of Muscular Function: Waiting for two years allows for a longer period to evaluate the stability of the child's muscular function. It ensures that the muscles involved in the tendon transfer operation have reached a more stable state, reducing the risk of unnecessary or premature surgical intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 2 months after the disease. Performing tendon transfer operation just two months after the onset of polio paralysis is very early in the course of the condition. At this stage, the child's muscles and nervous system may still be undergoing significant changes and adaptation following the acute phase of polio. The muscles affected by paralysis may not have stabilized, and there may still be potential for spontaneous recovery or improvement in muscle function. Additionally, operating too early may risk surgical complications or suboptimal outcomes due to the lack of adequate time for assessment and planning. Therefore, 2 months is unlikely to be the correct timing for tendon transfer operation in a child with polio paralysis.

 

Option C: 6-12 months after the disease. This timing allows for a reasonable period of observation and recovery following the acute phase of the disease. By waiting for 6 to 12 months, medical professionals can assess the stability of the child's muscle function and determine whether surgical intervention is necessary to improve function and prevent deformities. This timeframe also aligns with the concept of early intervention to address muscle weakness and prevent secondary complications, such as joint contractures. Therefore, option C is a plausible timing for tendon transfer operation in a child with polio paralysis.

 

Option D: After skeleton maturation. Delaying surgery until skeletal maturity may be considered when there are concerns about the child's growth potential, joint development, or when the risks of surgery outweigh the benefits at an earlier age. However, postponing surgery until skeletal maturation may also result in prolonged functional limitations, increased risk of joint deformities, and missed opportunities for early intervention to improve muscle function and mobility.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a 3-year-old child with polio paralysis, the tendon transfer option is done 2 years after the disease i.e., when the child turns 5 years old to observe the patient’s recovery and give time for the muscles to stabilize.

questions.text: What is the age of tendon transfer in post-polio residual paralysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 5 years

 

Option D:

 

TENDON TRANSFER IN POST POLIO RESIDUAL PARALYSIS

 

  • Post-polio residual paralysis refers to the long-term effects or sequelae of polio infection, which can include muscle weakness, atrophy, and paralysis.
  • Tendon transfer surgery is a common procedure used to improve muscle function and restore mobility in individuals with post-polio residual paralysis.
  • Performing tendon transfer surgery in individuals older than five years of age may be preferred for following reasons:
  • Skeletal Growth: By waiting until the child is older than five years, surgeons can ensure that skeletal growth and development are well underway. This reduces the risk of growth-related complications following surgery and allows for more accurate planning of the procedure.
  • Muscle Maturity: Tendon transfer surgery typically involves transferring tendons from healthy muscles to replace or augment the function of weakened or paralyzed muscles. Waiting until the child is older allows for better assessment of muscle maturity and function, which can improve the success and durability of the surgical outcomes.
  • Functional Assessment: Older children have had more time to adapt to their condition and develop compensatory strategies for mobility. Waiting until the child is older than five years allows for a more accurate assessment of functional limitations and goals, which can inform the decision-making process for tendon transfer surgery.
  • Patient Cooperation: Older children may have better cooperation and understanding of the surgical process and rehabilitation requirements, which can contribute to improved outcomes and adherence to post-operative care.
  • While waiting until the child is older than five years may be appropriate in many cases, it's important to note that the timing of tendon transfer surgery should be individualized based on the specific needs and circumstances of each patient.
  • Factors such as the severity of muscle weakness, functional limitations, and overall health should be carefully considered when determining the optimal timing for surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: < 6 months. This timing is highly unlikely and generally not considered appropriate due to skeletal immaturity and anesthesia risk.

 

Option B: 1 year. While this timing may be slightly more feasible compared to option A, it still raises similar concerns regarding skeletal immaturity, muscle function, and anesthesia risks.

 

Option C: 2 years. This timing represents a slightly older age compared to options A and B but still raises concerns regarding skeletal immaturity, muscle function, and anesthesia risks, although to a lesser extent.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • > 5 years of age is considered as an appropriate age for tendon transfer in post-polio residual paralysis, taking into account factors such as skeletal growth, muscle maturity, functional assessment, and patient cooperation.

choices.text: To assess the severity of damage of nerve
To classify the type of nerve injury
To locate the site of nerve injury
To assess the regeneration and recovery

questions.text: Tinel’s sign is used:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To assess the regeneration and recovery

 

Option D:

 

TINEL’S SIGN

 

  • Records regeneration rate by tapping on the nerve course from distal to proximal direction.
  • Tingling is felt at the sprouting nerve ends till the distal course of the nerve (Law of projection) and it disappears as myelinization takes place.
  • Rate of Recovery of Nerve is 1 mm/day.
  • Tinel’s is positive and progressive in axonotmesis and Sunderland type 2, 3 and 4.
  • Neuropraxia: Tinel’s sign negative
  • Tinel’s sign is positive and static in Neurotmesis and Sunderland type 5.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel’s sign is used to assess the regeneration rate and recovery rate of the nerves after the injury.

questions.text: Following nerve injury, the injured nerve regenerates at a rate of
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 0.1 cm/day

 

Option B:

 

NERVE REGENERATION

 

  • After nerve injuries, the injured neurons are required to regenerate the axons over long distances at a very slow rate of 1 mm/day i.e., 0.1 cm/day.
  • At this sluggish rate of regeneration, reestablishment of a functional motor unit or sense organ re-innervation may take months or even years.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The nerves regenerate at a rate of 0.1 cm/day after a nerve injury.

choices.text: Complete anatomic division of nerve is classified as Neurotmesis
Axonotmesis has Tinel’s sign positive and progressive
Neurotmesis has complete recovery with/without surgical intervention
Saturday night palsy involves radial nerve

questions.text: About Seddon’s Classification, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurotmesis has complete recovery with/without surgical intervention

 

Option C.

 

SEDDON’S CLASSIFICATION

 

  • Seddon classified peripheral nerve injuries into neuropraxia, axonotmesis, and neurotmesis. 
  • Neuropraxia:
    • It is temporary physiological disruption of nerve impulse conduction.
    • The loss of function is incomplete.
    • Complete recovery takes place in 3–6 weeks and it comes back like lightening, i.e. completely recovers in one go.
    • No Wallerian degeneration takes place and Tinel’s sign is negative.
      • Examples:
      • Crutch palsy (radial nerve or part of brachial plexus injured)
      • Saturday night palsy (radial nerve)
      • Tourniquet palsy
    • Few traumatic nerve injuries are neuropraxia.
  • Axonotmesis:
    • It is Axon breakdown.
    • Tinel’s sign is positive and Progressive.
    • Motor March is seen i.e., the recovery of muscles takes place in the order of their nerve supply from proximal to distal direction.
    • Recovery is usually not complete.
    • Seen in closed fractures and dislocations.
  • Neurotmesis:
    • Complete anatomic section of the nerve.
    • Tinel’s sign is positive and non-progressive.
    • No recovery without surgical intervention.
    • Even with intervention, may not have complete recovery.
    • Degeneration distal to injuries – Secondary or Wallerian degeneration
    • Degeneration in proximal segment – Primary or retrograde degeneration
    • At proximal end forms — Neuroma
    • At distal end forms— Glioma

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Complete anatomic division of nerve is classified as neurotemesis.
  • Axonotmesis has Tinel’s sign positive and progressive.
  • Neurotmesis do not have a complete recovery with/without surgical intervention.
  • Saturday night palsy involves radial nerve neuropraxia.

questions.text: Sunderland classification is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury

 

Option A.

 

SUNDERLAND CLASSIFICATION

 

  • Sunderland Classification in Relation to Seddon’s:
    • Type I – Neuropraxia
    • Type II, III, IV – Axonotmesis
    • Type V – Neurotmesis
  • Sunderland classified nerve injuries into five types but sometimes sixth-degree (Mackinnon) or mixed injuries occur in which a nerve trunk is partially severed and the remaining part of the trunk sustains fourth, third, second, or rarely even first-degree injury.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Muscle injury. The British Athletics muscle injury classification (BAMIC) is a five-point MRI-based system that is based on extent and site. It has been primarily based on hamstring injuries but is used in other muscle injuries.

 

Option C. Tendon injury. Based on the anatomy of the tendon, it is possible to describe four pathologic conditions i.e., Peritenonitis, Peritenonitis with tendinosis, Tendinosis, and Tendinitis.

 

Option D. Ligament injury. They are graded from 1st to 3rd degree.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sunderland classification is used to classify the nerve injuries.

questions.text: While performing flexor tendon graft repair, graft is taken from:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmaris longus

 

Option B.

 

TENDON GRAFT

 

  • The Palmaris longus muscle, located superficially along the inner side of the forearm, is often utilized as a graft source during flexor tendon repairs.
  • This muscle is chosen due to its expendability and similarity in function to the flexor tendons.
  • However, it should be noted that not everyone possesses a Palmaris longus tendon, as it is absent in approximately 10-20% of individuals.
  • In such instances, alternative graft sources such as the plantaris tendon is used.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plantaris. The plantaris tendon is a small, thin tendon located in the calf. It is not commonly used for flexor tendon graft repair due to its relatively small size and limited function. Additionally, harvesting the plantaris tendon may not provide adequate strength or length for effective tendon grafting in flexor tendon repair.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum. The extensor digitorum tendon is located on the dorsal aspect of the forearm and hand. They are responsible for extending the fingers and wrist. This tendon is not typically used for flexor tendon graft repair because it serves the opposite function of flexion.

 

Option D. Extensor indicis. The extensor indicis tendon is also located on the dorsal aspect of the forearm and hand. It is responsible for extending the index finger. Like the extensor digitorum, this tendon is not commonly used for flexor tendon graft repair due to its role in finger extension rather than flexion.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The palmaris longus tendon is a slender, relatively superficial tendon located in the forearm.
  • It is commonly used as a graft for flexor tendon repair due to its accessibility, adequate length, and minimal functional deficit after harvesting.
  • Additionally, many individuals have a palmaris longus tendon that is easily identified, making it a convenient choice for tendon grafting in flexor tendon repair surgeries.

choices.text: C8-T1 nerve roots
Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: A patient woke up in the morning with an inability to extend digits. The rest of the sensory and motor examination of hand was normal. Which nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior interosseous nerve

 

Option B.

 

POSTERIOR INTEROSSEOUS NERVE

 

  • Radial nerve supplies the wrist extensors.
  • In the forearm, Radial nerve divides at the head of radius into two branches – Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve and Posterior Interosseous nerve.
  • This superficial branch provides the sensory supply to the dorsum of the hand (two and a half fingers) except the nailbeds.
  • Posterior interosseous nerve is a purely motor branch which supplies the finger extensors.
  • So, if only extensor (motor) functions are lost – Posterior Interosseous nerve is affected.
  • Note: If wrist extension absent then radial nerve is answer
  • Other Motor and Sensory examination of hand being normal rules out Option A, C and D.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C8-T1 roots. It supplies the medial 1 ½ fingers and controls flexion at MCP joints and extension at IP joints. Injury to these roots result in Ulnar Claw Hand.

 

Option C. Radial nerve. Injury to Radial nerve will not only affect the extensor function but will also cause sensory loss in the 1st web-space on the dorsum of the hand.

 

Option D. Lower brachial plexus. injury will also cause sensory loss.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of posterior interosseous nerve injury.

choices.text: No endoneurial tube
Glial scar formation
Absence of growth factors
Lack of myelin inhibitors

questions.text: A politician was shot by a gun in back in political rally at T8 level, after which he developed paraplegia. The fact that the injured nerve is not able to regenerate is due to all the reasons except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lack of myelin inhibitors

 

Option D.

 

NERVE REGENERATION

 

  • Potential ways to improve neuronal regeneration in the CNS:
  1. Act on the secondary cell death process: so, block apoptosis and help neurons survive.
  2. Neurotrophic factors: BDNF (brain derived neurotrophic factor) is the best studied. It does help injured neurons survive. Also helps axons grow. But, should be viewed with caution since injecting a growth factor into the CNS can cause uncontrolled growth (potentially carcinogenic).
  3. Remove growth inhibitors:
  • Astrocyte associated: As part of scarring process, astrocytes lay down chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans. The signal from the chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans acts as a stop signal for axon growth. Adding a chondroitinase (cleaves off chondroitin sulfate) promotes axon regrowth in injured area.
  • Myelin-associated inhibitors (from oligodendrocytes): there are 3 different ones that are all recognized by axons as stop signals: myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG), oligodendrocyte myelin glycoprotein (OMgp), and Nogo.
  • A cell surface receptor binds any one of the 3, activates a protein kinase involved in the breakdown of cytoskeletal elements that are needed for process outgrowth.
  • A TAJ knock-out of the myelin associated inhibitors works to inhibit the inhibitor and promote axon growth.
  1. PNS nerve graft: Provides basal lamina (called ‘’bands of bungner”). Works to some extent. But unclear if it is the nerve graft itself that is working, or the fact that you’ve caused inflammation and subsequently dumped in a bunch of activated macrophages.
  2. Glial Scar inhibits nerve regeneration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. No endoneurial tube. Endoneurial tubes are protective sheaths that surround individual nerve fibers within a peripheral nerve. These tubes provide structural support and contain essential elements for nerve regeneration, such as blood vessels and extracellular matrix components. If these tubes are disrupted or damaged, it can impede nerve regeneration. However, the absence of endoneurial tubes is not a typical reason for the inability of nerves to regenerate after injury.

 

Option B. Glial scar formation. After nerve injury, glial cells react by forming a scar tissue composed of glial cells and extracellular matrix components. While this scar tissue can provide structural support and prevent further damage, it can also create a physical and biochemical barrier that inhibits nerve regeneration. Glial scar formation is a significant factor contributing to the failure of nerve regeneration after injury.

 

Option C. Absence of growth factors. Growth factors play a crucial role in promoting nerve regeneration by stimulating axonal growth, promoting cell survival, and facilitating the remyelination process. In the absence of adequate growth factors, nerve regeneration can be significantly impaired. Therefore, the absence of growth factors is a valid reason for the failure of nerve regeneration after injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Myelin inhibitors are proteins present in the myelin sheath of nerves that inhibit axonal growth.
  • In conditions where these inhibitors are absent or downregulated, such as after nerve injury, axonal growth can occur more readily.
  • Therefore, the lack of myelin inhibitors would not hinder nerve regeneration; rather, it would potentially facilitate it.

choices.text: In all cases of open wound with clinical signs of nerve injury, nerve exploration should always be done
Nerve conduction velocity is best predictor within 48 hours of injury
Positive Tinel’s sign indicates the accurate location of lesion
Traction nerve injury should be repaired immediately

questions.text: Which of the following is true about nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) In all cases of open wound with clinical signs of nerve injury, nerve exploration should always be done.

 

Option A.

 

NERVE INJURY

 

  • Nerve injuries with wound should always be explored and if nerve is in continuity, then it is treated like closed injury.
  • If there is a clean cut, then it is primarily repaired and if ends are crushed, debridement is done and then repaired later.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nerve conduction velocity is best predictor within 48 hours of injury. False. Nerve conduction velocity usually predicts about nerve injury between days 10 and 14.
 

Option C. Positive Tinel’s sign indicates the accurate location of lesion. False. Tinel’s sign can predict the rate of nerve recovery and its speed of regeneration based upon the level of unmyelinated free nerve endings.

 

Option D. Traction nerve injury should be repaired immediately. False. Traction nerve injuries are managed with expectant approach of wait and watch for recovery and then if recovery does not take place then it needs exploration and repair.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In cases of an open wound with the clinical signs suggesting nerve injury, nerve exploration should always be done.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Tinel’s sign is positive and progressive in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axonotmesis

 

Option A.

 

TINEL’S SIGN

 

  • Records regeneration rate by tapping on the nerve course from distal to proximal direction.
  • Tingling is felt at the sprouting nerve ends and it disappears as myelinization takes place
  • Rate of Recovery: 1 mm/day
  • Tinel’s is positive and progressive in axonotmesis and Sunderland 2 and 3.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neurotmesis. In this nerve injury, the Tinel’s sign is positive and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Neuropraxia. In this injury, the Tinel’s sign is negative.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel’s sign is positive and progressive in axonotmesis.
  • It is positive and non-progressive in neurotmesis.
  • It is negative in neuropraxia.

questions.text: Nerve with best recovery is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radial nerve

 

Option D.

 

NERVE RECOVERY

 

  • Radial nerve has the best prognosis, followed by median nerve > ulnar nerve > peroneal nerve > sciatic nerve (worst prognosis).
  • Best prognosis after nerve repair:
    • Radial nerve
    • After repair of the radial nerve, the prognosis for regeneration is more favorable than for any other major nerve in the upper extremity, primarily because is predominantly a motor nerve and secondarily because the muscles innervated by it are not involved in the finer movements of the fingers and hand.
  • Worst prognosis after nerve repair in the upper extremity:
    • Ulnar nerve
    • As it is mainly a sensory nerve and also is concerned with finer movements of the hands and fingers.
  • Worst prognosis after nerve repair:
    • Sciatic nerve
    • Because of the extensive retrograde neuronal degeneration, intraneural intermixing of regenerating fibers with loss of fiber localization and degenerative changes in the distal muscles that must remain denervated for a long time.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the nerves that recover completely from a nerve injury, the order is as follows:

 

  • Radial nerve (best prognosis)
  • Median nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Peroneal nerve
  • Sciatic nerve (worst prognosis)

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Motor march is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axonotmesis

 

Option A.

 

MOTOR MARCH

 

  • Motor march refers to the recovery of the muscle in the order of its nerve supply from proximal to distal direction.
  • This is seen in axonotmesis.
  • It is a sign of re-innervation of the nerve.
  • It may also be observed in the repaired neurotmesis.
  • The commonest example of this phenomenon is the radial nerve injury in radial groove in shaft of humerus fractures. The first muscle that would recover is the brachioradialis followed by Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) and further distally sequentially.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Motor march is the sign of re-innervation of the nerve after the axon breakdown in axonotmesis.
  • It is not seen in neuropraxia and neurotmesis but is seen in a repaired neurotmesis.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint and wait and watch
