Exploration of the nerve

questions.text: A patient after sleeping on chair with hanging arm whole night presents with weakness in muscles supplied by ulnar nerve, causing claw hand. It is managed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knuckle bender splint and wait and watch.

 

Option B.

 

ULNAR CALW HAND MANAGEMENT

 

  • Neuropraxia is physiological block in nerve conduction and this is a case of Saturday night palsy causing ulnar nerve symptoms.
  • The management is expectant, i.e., wait and watch and till the meantime, splint is given that is knuckle bender splint for ulnar nerve palsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electrophysiological studies. While electrophysiological studies such as nerve conduction studies and electromyography (EMG) can help diagnose nerve compression or injury, they are not typically used as the primary management for this condition. Instead, they are more useful for confirming the diagnosis and assessing the severity of nerve damage.

 

Option C. Exploration of the nerve. Nerve exploration surgery involves surgically accessing the ulnar nerve to identify and address any compression or injury. While this option may be necessary in some cases, it is typically reserved for severe or refractory cases that do not respond to conservative management.

 

Option D. Tendon transfer. Tendon transfer surgery can be considered for correcting the claw hand deformity caused by ulnar nerve palsy, but it is usually reserved for cases where conservative measures have failed or when there is permanent nerve damage.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Knuckle splint use and wait and watch allows for conservative management while closely monitoring the patient's progress in this case scenario.
  • If symptoms persist or worsen despite splinting, further interventions such as surgical exploration or tendon transfer may be considered.
  • However, initial management often begins with conservative measures like splinting.

choices.text: Common peroneal nerve

questions.text: Prognosis after secondary nerve suturing is better in pure than in mixed ones. Based on this criterion, which one of the following nerves should be given the best result after suturing in identical conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

Option B.

 

NERVE RECOVERY AFTER NERVE SUTURING

 

  • Radial nerve has the best prognosis, followed by median nerve > ulnar nerve > peroneal nerve > sciatic nerve (worst prognosis).
  • Best prognosis after nerve repair:
    • Radial nerve
    • After repair of the radial nerve, the prognosis for regeneration is more favorable than for any other major nerve in the upper extremity, primarily because is predominantly a motor nerve and secondarily because the muscles innervated by it are not involved in the finer movements of the fingers and hand.
  • Worst prognosis after nerve repair in the upper extremity:
    • Ulnar nerve
    • As it is mainly a sensory nerve and also is concerned with finer movements of the hands and fingers.
  • Worst prognosis after nerve repair:
    • Sciatic nerve
    • Because of the extensive retrograde neuronal degeneration, intraneural intermixing of regenerating fibers with loss of fiber localization and degenerative changes in the distal muscles that must remain denervated for a long time.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the nerves that recover from a nerve injury and following nerve suturing, the order is as follows:

 

  • Radial nerve (best prognosis)
  • Median nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Peroneal nerve
  • Sciatic nerve (worst prognosis)

choices.text: Creatine phosphokinase levels

questions.text: A pole vaulter had a fall during pole vaulting and had paralysis of the arm. Which of the following investigations gives the best recovery prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electromyography

 

Option A.

 

NERVE INVESTIGATION

 

  • EMG is a diagnostic test used to assess the health of muscles and the nerve cells that control them.
  • It measures the electrical activity in muscles and nerves.
  • While EMG can help identify nerve damage or dysfunction, it primarily provides information about the current status of the nerves and muscles rather than predicting recovery prognosis.
  • Thus, EMG (electromyography) is by far the most reliable and effective test to predict about nerve recovery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Muscle biopsy. Muscle biopsy is typically used to diagnose muscle diseases or disorders, such as muscular dystrophy. While it can provide valuable information about the condition of the muscles, it may not be the most relevant investigation for assessing recovery prognosis in the context of a nerve injury.

 

Option C. Strength-duration curve. A strength-duration curve is a graph that represents the relationship between the intensity and duration of an electrical stimulus required to elicit a muscle contraction. This curve is used primarily in electrotherapy to determine optimal parameters for neuromuscular stimulation. While it can provide information about the excitability of nerves and muscles, it may not directly predict recovery prognosis following a nerve injury.

 

Option D. Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. Creatine phosphokinase is an enzyme found in muscles, and elevated levels of CPK in the blood can indicate muscle damage or injury. However, in the context of a nerve injury such as paralysis following a fall during pole vaulting, CPK levels may not directly correlate with recovery prognosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most relevant investigation for assessing nerve function and potential for recovery in the given context would be electromyography (EMG).
  • EMG can provide valuable information about the extent of nerve damage and the potential for nerve regeneration, which can help inform the prognosis for recovery.

choices.text: After one day

questions.text: Nerve suturing in a clean-cut injury is done best in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 hours

 

Option A.

 

NERVE SUTURING

 

  • In cases of nerve injury, particularly clean cut injuries, the timing of nerve suturing, also known as nerve repair or nerve anastomosis, is critical for achieving optimal outcomes and functional recovery.
  • The goal of nerve suturing is to re-establish continuity and alignment of the nerve fibers, facilitating nerve regeneration and restoration of function.
  • The correct timing for nerve suturing depends on various factors, including the extent of the injury, the type of nerve involved, and the condition of the surrounding tissues.
  • In general, the earlier the nerve repair is performed, the better the outcomes tend to be.
  • In open injuries,
    • Primary repair: Within 6–8 hours
    • Delayed primary repair: 7–18 days
    • Secondary repair: After 18 days

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 12 hours. While still within a relatively early timeframe, delaying repair beyond 6 hours may slightly decrease the likelihood of optimal outcomes compared to earlier repair.

 

Option C. After one day. Delaying nerve suturing for more than 24 hours after the injury significantly reduces the chances of successful nerve regeneration and functional recovery. Nerve fibers may begin to degenerate, and the ends of the nerve may retract, making it more challenging to achieve proper alignment during repair.

 

Option D. After two days. Further delaying nerve suturing beyond two days greatly diminishes the chances of successful nerve regeneration. By this time, significant degeneration and scarring may have occurred, making it much more difficult to achieve satisfactory outcomes with nerve repair alone.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • 6 hours timeframe allows for prompt repair, maximizing the chances of successful nerve regeneration and functional recovery.
  • It is crucial to perform nerve suturing as soon as possible after the injury to optimize outcomes and minimize long-term deficits.
  • Delaying repair beyond this timeframe may compromise the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and the patient's ultimate recovery.

choices.text: Pure motor nerve injury

questions.text: Following indicates better prognosis in nerve injury except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proximal injury

 

Option D.

 

GOOD PROGNOSIS FACTORS FOR NERVE INJURY

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The good prognostic factors for nerve injury recovery are a young growing age, pure motor or pure sensory nerve involvement, distal injury/lesion, neuropraxia, early repair, radial nerve involvement, maintained vascularity, and end-to-end repair.
  • Proximal nerve injuries do not have a good prognosis.

choices.text: 2, 3 and 5 are correct
1, 2 and 3 are correct
1 and 3 are correct

questions.text:
What is true about Erb’s Palsy? 

 

  1. Adduction + Internal rotation
  2. Supination seen
  3. C5, C6 roots affected
  4. Lower trunk injury causes this deformity
  5. Claw hand is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3 are correct

 

Option C.

 

ERB’S PALSY

 

  • Best prognosis amongst brachial plexus injuries.
  • Erb’s palsy is the commonest brachial plexus injury and commonest injury causing neurological deficit in upper limb.
  • Mode of Injury:
    • Excessive downward stretching of shoulder on same side and head toward opposite side, e.g., Blow or fall on shoulder/delivery.
  • Site of Injury:
    • Upper Trunk
    • Upper C5 and C6 roots of brachial plexus – Erb’s point where 6 nerves meet.
  1. Musculocutaneous Nerve
  2. Axillary Nerve
  3. Nerve to subclavius
  4. Suprascapular Nerve
  5. C5 Nerve
  6. C6 Nerve
  • Deformity and Loss of Movements (FAbEr’S Lost in Erb’s):
    • Policeman/Waiter/Porter’s tip hand
      • Arm adducted and medially rotated
      • Forearm extended and pronated
      • Arm hangs limply by the side


         
    • Lost movements: All movements opposite to the deformity would be lost, i.e.:
      • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of arm
      • Loss of flexion and supination of forearm

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Adduction + Internal rotation. True. The deformity in Erb’s palsy is adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder because of the loss of abduction and external rotation movements.

 

  1. Supination seen. False. Supination movement is lost in the Erb’s palsy, thus the forearm appears pronated.

 

  1. C5, C6 roots affected. True. The cause of Erb’s palsy is the brachial plexus injury. The most commonly affected region of the brachial plexus in this condition is the upper trunk, involving C5-C6 nerve roots.

 

  1. Lower trunk injury causes this deformity. False. This injury is caused by the injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus i.e., C5-C6 nerve roots.

 

  1. Claw hand is seen. False. The deformity characteristically seen in the Erb’s palsy is the policeman’s/waiter’s/porter’s tip hand.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Erb’s palsy is caused by the injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, involving C5-C6 nerve roots.
  • This causes loss of shoulder abduction and external rotation, forearm supination movements.
  • This loss of movements leads to the presentation of the shoulder in adduction and internal rotation, and forearm in pronation, called as policeman’s tip hand deformity.

choices.text: Involves lower trunk of brachial plexus
Intrinsic muscles of hand are paralyzed
Claw hand is a feature
Horner’s syndrome can never be associated

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Klumpke’s paralysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Horner’s syndrome can never be associated

 

Option D.

 

KLUMPKE’S PALSY

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is lower plexus injury.
  • C8 and T1 nerve roots are involved.
  • It is much less common, but more severe.
  • Wrist and finger flexors are weak and the intrinsic hand muscles are paralyzed.
  • Sensation is lost in ulnar forearm and there may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Involves lower trunk of brachial plexus. True. The klumpke’s palsy involved the lower trunk of the brachial plexus i.e., the C8-T1 nerve roots.

 

Option B. Intrinsic muscles of hand are paralyzed. True. The wrist and finger flexors become weak, while the intrinsic muscles of the hand are paralyzed.

 

Option C. Claw hand is a feature. True. The combination of weakness of the wrist and finger flexors and paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of hand leads to a characteristic claw hand deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Unilateral Horner’s syndrome is an important association of the Klumpke’s palsy.

choices.text: C5, C6 roots
C6, C7 roots
C7, C8 roots

questions.text: Erb’s palsy involves injury to
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C5, C6 roots

 

Option A.

 

ERB’S PALSY

 

  • Best prognosis amongst brachial plexus injuries.
  • Erb’s palsy is the most common brachial plexus injury and commonest injury causing neurological deficit in upper limb.
  • Mode of Injury:
    • Excessive downward stretching of shoulder on same side and head toward opposite side, e.g., Blow or fall on shoulder/delivery.
  • Site of Injury:
    • Upper Trunk
    • Upper C5 and C6 roots of brachial plexus – Erb’s point where 6 nerves meet.
  1. Musculocutaneous Nerve
  2. Axillary Nerve
  3. Nerve to subclavius
  4. Suprascapular Nerve
  5. C5 Nerve
  6. C6 Nerve

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Erb’s palsy involves injury to the C5-C6 nerve roots.
  • C8-T1 nerve roots are involved in the Klumpke’s palsy.

choices.text: Policeman tip deformity
Winging of scapula

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is evident in case of Erb’s palsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Policeman tip deformity

 

Option A.

 

ERB’S PALSY

 

  • Erb’s palsy is characterized by weakness or paralysis of the arm particularly, the muscles of the shoulder and upper arm.
  • It occurs as a result of injury or damage to the brachial plexus.
  • Most commonly it occurs during childbirth due to excessive stretching or tearing of the brachial plexus nerves, due to excessive lateral traction.
  • The deformity occurs is called Policeman’s Tip Deformity.

 

 

 

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Shoulder – Adducted, Internally Rotated
    • Elbow – Pronated, Extended
    • Wrist – Flexed
    • Asymmetrical Moro’s Reflex

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Winging of scapula. In a patient with a winged scapula, the medial or lateral aspect of the scapula appears to be protruding from the back. It can create a winged appearance. The most common etiology of a winged scapula is damaged or impaired innervation to the serratus anterior muscle. The nerve that innervates this muscle is the long thoracic nerve. Some patients may also complain of an inability to raise the affected arm above their head. 

 

 

Option C. Claw hand. When the ulnar nerve is injured, the muscles innervated by the nerve begin to weaken. This leads to an imbalance between the strong extrinsic muscles (i.e., extensor digitorum communis) and the weakened intrinsic muscles (i.e., interossei and lumbricals). This imbalance is characterized clinically by metacarpophalangeal (MCP) hyperextension and proximal interphalangeal (PIP), and distal interphalangeal (DIP) flexion, known as claw hand deformity.

 

 

Option D. Wrist drop. Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits, those whose radial nerve function has been compromised cannot actively extend them. As such, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. Causes of wrist drop can range for penetrative trauma to external compression (Saturday night palsy) to systemic nutritional deficiencies.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In Erb’s palsy, policeman’s tip deformity is evident which involves shoulder adduction and medial rotation, forearm extension and pronation while the arm hangs limply by the side of the trunk.

choices.text: Radial nerve injury
Ulnar nerve injury
Brachial plexus injury

questions.text: Aeroplane splint is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brachial plexus injury

 

Option C.

 

BRACHIAL PLEXUS INJURY SPLINT

 

  • The objectives are to regain shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, wrist extension, finger flexion, and sensibility over the hand.
  • Aeroplane splint is used for brachial plexus palsy.
  • The aeroplane splint is a well-known method of maintaining an angle of 90° at the axilla.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve injury. For the wrist drop in radial nerve injury, a cock-up splint is used to keep the wrist and fingers in extension.

 

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve injury. For the claw hand due to ulnar nerve injury, knuckle bender splint is used.

 

 

Option D. Scoliosis. The Milwaukee brace, which is the original cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) is an older and bulkier brace for scoliosis. It is used for curves in the thoracic or cervical spine. The most-commonly prescribed brace for scoliosis today is the Boston brace. It is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (TLSO).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The aeroplane splint is used in the brachial plexus to keep the arm in abduction.

questions.text: Muscles paralyzed in Erb’s paralysis are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Triceps

 

Option B.

 

MUSCLES AFFECTED IN ERB’S PALSY

 

  • Deficits as a result of brachial plexus injury:

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the Erb’s palsy, biceps brachii, brachioradialis and brachialis muscles are paralysed.
  • Trcieps muscle is not affected the Erb’s palsy.

questions.text: Klumpke’s paralysis involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C8-T1

 

Option D.

 

KLUMPKE’S PALSY

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is lower plexus injury.
  • C8 and T1 nerve roots are involved.
  • It is much less common, but more severe.
  • Wrist and finger flexors are weak and the intrinsic hand muscles are paralyzed.
  • Sensation is lost in ulnar forearm and there may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Klumpke’s paralysis involves the lower trunk of the brachial plexus i.e., C8-T1.

choices.text: Radial nerve entrapment
Thoracic outlet syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-male present with abrupt onset pain, weakness, loss of contour of shoulder and wasting of muscle of arm on 5th day of tetanus toxoid immunization in deltoid. Likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brachial neuritis

 

Option C.

 

BRACHIAL NEURITIS

 

  • Brachial neuritis consists of acute onset of severe shoulder or scapular pain followed over days to weeks by weakness of the proximal arm and shoulder girdle muscles innervated by the upper brachial plexus.
  • The onset is often preceded by infection, recent illness, surgery, immunization, or even trauma.
  • Complete recovery occurs in 75% cases in 2 years.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve entrapment. Radial nerve entrapment is an uncommon diagnosis. The most location of entrapment is the proximal forearm. Radial nerve entrapment often results from overuse but can occur secondary to other causes such as direct trauma, fractures, lacerations, compressive devices, or post-surgical changes. Symptoms usually develop very slowly. Symptoms include pain, sensory and motor changes, paresthesias, and/or paralysis limited to the dorsoradial aspect of the distal forearm and hand. If radial nerve entrapment has resulted in only mild damage (neurapraxia), recovery should be rapid and complete in 2 to 8 weeks. However, more severe injuries (axonotmesis) will recover more slowly.

 

Option B. Thoracic outlet syndrome. Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) manifests when pressures in the thoracic outlet increase to the point of impinging vessels or nerves. These pressures can result from several anatomical abnormalities, such as the thoracic ribs or space-occupying lesions, including tumors or cysts. Nebulous pain is one of the most common complaints. Venous obstruction can present with upper extremity swelling, venous distention, and pain ranging from the hand to the forearm. Upper extremity deep venous thromboses (DVTs) can also be present. Patients who undergo conservative therapy have their symptoms resolve in about 90% of cases.

 

Option D. Hysteria. Histrionic personality disorder (HPD) is characterized by a pervasive pattern of attention-seeking behaviours and a theatrical level of emotional reactions. The condition is usually life-long, though onset is typically in late adolescence or early adulthood. Individuals with HPD are often described as narcissistic, self-indulgent, flirtatious, dramatic, extroverted, and animated. Individuals with HPD may feel underappreciated or disregarded when they are not the center of attention. They may be vibrant, enchanting, overly seductive, or inappropriately sexual. People presenting with HPD typically demonstrate rapidly shifting and shallow emotions that others may perceive as insincere. Several factors are believed to contribute to the development of HPD, including genetic predisposition, childhood experiences, and environmental influences. Ultimately, HPD is unlikely to resolve on its own or with treatment.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described history and symptoms of the patient after an immunization are suggestive of brachial neuritis.

choices.text: Preganglionic lesions have a better prognosis than postganglionic lesions
Erb’s palsy causes paralysis of the abductors and external rotators of the shoulder
In Klumpke’s palsy, Horner’s syndrome may be present on the ipsilateral side
Histamine test is useful to differentiate between the preganglionic and postganglionic lesions

questions.text: All are true regarding brachial plexus injury, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Preganglionic lesions have a better prognosis than postganglionic lesions.

 

Option A.

 

BRACHIAL PLEXUS INJURY

 

  • Preganglionic lesions have a poor prognosis as these do not recover and are surgically irreparable.
  • Postganglionic lesions have better prognosis than preganglionic lesions and histamine test is useful in making the distinction.
  • In case of a preganglionic injury, the nerve is avulsed from spinal cord, separating motor neurons from the motor centres of the ventral horns of the spinal cord.
  • Sensory neurons remain intact at the level of dorsal root ganglion, which explains why sensory nerve action potentials are preserved in preganglionic lesions.
  • Preganglionic lesions are not repairable and alternative working motor nerves need to be transferred in order to restore part of the functionality of the upper limp.
  • Contrarily, postganglionic lesions may be restored spontaneously (in case of axonotmesis) or may be repaired surgically because there is rupture of a nerve root distal to ganglion, or of a trunk or peripheral nerve.
  • In these lesions, both sensory and motor action potentials are influenced since both sensory and motor rootlets are ruptured.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erb’s palsy causes paralysis of the abductors and external rotators of the shoulder. True. In Erb’s palsy, the shoulder abduction and external rotation movements are lost, leading to the presentation of shoulder in adduction and internal rotation.

 

Option C. In Klumpke’s palsy, Horner’s syndrome may be present on the ipsilateral side. True. Klumpke’s paralysis also manifest as unilateral (ipsilateral) Horner’s syndrome.

 

Option D. Histamine test is useful to differentiate between the preganglionic and postganglionic lesions. True. The purpose of the histamine test is to differentiate preganglionic and postganglionic lesions. The intradermal injection of histamine causes triple response (red reaction due to capillary dilatation, wheal due to fluid extravasation from increased permeability, and flare due to arteriolar dilatation and to axon reflex in sensory nerve). If there is response with flare in an otherwise unconscious skin area, then the lesion has to be proximal to the dorsal root ganglion, which means that it must be a root avulsion injury. On the contrary, when the lesion is postganglionic the test will be negative as the continuity between the skin and dorsal root ganglion will have been interrupted.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The preganglionic brachial plexus lesions have a poor prognosis because the nerve avulses from the spinal cord, so it cannot be repaired.
  • The postganglionic lesions restore spontaneously or may require surgery, but have a better prognosis than preganglionic lesions.

questions.text: All of the following muscles undergo paralysis after injury to C5 and C6 spinal nerves except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coracobrachialis

 

Option B.

 

C5-C6 NERVE INJURY

 

  • Coracobrachialis receives its supply from C5/C6/C7 but other three only from C5 and C6.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Biceps. The biceps brachii muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which originates from the C5-C6 nerve roots. Therefore, injury to the C5 and C6 spinal nerves would lead to paralysis of the biceps muscle.

 

Option C. Brachialis. The brachialis muscle is primarily innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which arises from the C5-C6 nerve roots. Therefore, injury to the C5 and C6 spinal nerves would result in paralysis of the brachialis muscle.

 

Option D. Brachioradialis. The brachioradialis muscle is innervated by the radial nerve, which receives contributions from the C5-C8 nerve roots. Therefore, injury to the C5 and C6 spinal nerves alone would not directly lead to paralysis of the brachioradialis muscle. However, it's worth noting that the brachioradialis can be weakened to some extent due to the loss of support from other muscles if there's significant injury affecting the entire C5-C8 nerve distribution.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to the injury to the C5-C6 spinal nerve roots, there will be paralysis of the biceps, brachialis and the brachioradialis but there will be no effect on the corachobrachialis because it is supplied by the C5-C7 nerve roots while the other three are supplied by the C5-C6 nerve roots.

choices.text: Fracture-dislocation of cervical spine

questions.text: Most common cause of neurological deficit in upper limb is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erb’s palsy

 

Option B.

 

ERB’S PALSY

 

  • Erb’s palsy is the commonest brachial plexus injury and commonest injury causing neurological deficit in upper limb.
  • It is caused by injury to the brachial plexus, which is formed from the ventral rami of cervical nerves 5 to 8 (C5-C8) and thoracic nerve 1 (T1).
  • The brachial plexus innervates all muscles of the upper limb except the trapezius.
  • Erb’s palsy occurs when the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, comprising C5 and C6, is severed. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Polio. Polio is a viral infectious disease caused by the poliovirus. While polio primarily affects the motor neurons in the spinal cord and can lead to muscle weakness and paralysis, it is not the most common cause of neurological deficit in the upper limb.

 

Option C. C1–C2 dislocation. Dislocation of the C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) vertebrae is a serious injury that can result from trauma, such as a high-speed motor vehicle accident or a severe fall. This type of injury can cause compression or injury to the spinal cord, leading to neurological deficits. However, C1–C2 dislocation is relatively uncommon compared to other causes of neurological deficit in the upper limb.

 

Option D. Fracture-dislocation of cervical spine. Fracture-dislocation of the cervical spine involves both a vertebral fracture and displacement of the affected vertebrae, often due to significant trauma such as a motor vehicle accident or a fall from height. This type of injury can result in compression or injury to the spinal cord, leading to neurological deficits not only in the upper limb but also potentially affecting other regions of the body. While it is a serious injury, fracture-dislocation of the cervical spine may not be the most common cause of neurological deficit specifically in the upper limb.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of neurological deficit in the upper limb is the erb’s palsy caused due to brachial plexus injury at C5-C6 nerve root level.

choices.text: Loss of flexion of shoulder
Loss of flexion at elbow
Loss of supination of forearm
Loss of sensation on radial side of forearm

questions.text: All of the following are features of musculocutaneous nerve injury at axilla except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of flexion of shoulder

 

Option A.

 

MUSCULOCUTANEOUS NERVE INJURY

 

  • Musculocutaneous nerve supplies coracobrachialis, the biceps brachii and the brachialis, and is continued into the forearm as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.
  • In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm.
  • It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the injury of the musculocutaneous nerve, the shoulder flexion is not lost but it becomes weak.
  • Shoulder flexion can still be performed by the pectoralis major muscle.
  • The elbow flexion and forearm supination are lost from this nerve injury.
  • There is also sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the forearm.

questions.text: A patient presented with Paresthesia and loss of sensation over lower part of deltoid. X-ray showed fracture surgical neck of humerus. Likely nerve to be involved is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve

 

Option B.

 

AXILLARY NERVE (C5-C6) INJURY

 

  • Axillary nerve is injured in fracture of surgical neck humerus, shoulder dislocation (anterior and inferior) and intramuscular injections.

 

 

X-ray showing fracture of the surgical neck of humerus

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Deltoid muscle palsy
    • Loss of rounded contour of shoulder, giving shoulder a flattened appearance and produce hollow inferior to acromion
    • Weakness of abduction (15°-90°)
    • Teres minor palsy
  • Sensory involvement:
    • Lateral cutaneous nerve of arm
    • Sensory loss over lower half of deltoid (regimental badge area).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Musculocutaneous nerve. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Option C. Radial nerve. Common causes of radial nerve injuries are fractures of the humerus (spiral fracture along the distal third of the humerus (Holstein-Lewis fracture)), improper use of crutches, overuse of the arm (secondary to manual labor, chronic overuse, or sport-related participation), and work-related accidents. A patient may complain of decreased or absent sensation on the dorsoradial side of hand and wrist with an inability to extend wrist, thumb, and fingers. This is also referred to as "wrist drop.” If damaged at the axilla, there will be a loss of extension of the forearm, hand, and fingers. There will be a sensory loss in the lateral arm and posterior aspect of the forearm, radiating to the radial aspect of the dorsal hand and digits. This is seen commonly with "Saturday night palsy" and improperly using crutches (crutch palsy).

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, arthritic changes, and valgus deformities at the elbow increase its vulnerability to injury. The patient may have numbness and paresthesia, radiating distally to the ulnar aspect of the hand, the fifth digit and the ulnar aspect of the fourth digit. It is usually associated with elbow flexion, particularly at night. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to the fracture of the surgical neck of humerus, the most commonly affected nerve is the axillary nerve.
  • Injury to the axillary nerve causes paresthesia and loss of sensation over the lower part of the deltoid, known as the regimental badge area.

questions.text: Axillary nerve injury is likely to be seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shoulder dislocation

 

Axillary Nerve Injury Etiology

 

  • Axillary neuropathies are due to traumatic injuries, traction injuries, quadrilateral space syndrome, and brachial neuritis (also called neuralgic amyotrophy or Parsonage-Turner syndrome).
  • An anterior dislocation and forced abduction of the shoulder joint appear to be common causes of axillary nerve injury in young people.
  • Axillary nerve is also injured in fracture of surgical neck humerus, and intramuscular injections.
  • The axillary nerve is most susceptible to injury at the origin from the posterior cord, in the quadrilateral space, the anteroinferior aspect of the shoulder capsule, and within the subfascial surface of the deltoid muscle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Coracoid process fracture. In fractures involving the coracoid process, there may be compression of the brachial plexus and suprascapular nerve paralysis. 

 

Option C. Humerus shaft fracture. This is involved with injury to the radial nerve. 

 

Option D. Brachial plexus injury. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus leads to Erbs palsy while that of the lower trunk leads to Klumpkes palsy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

An axillary nerve injury is commonly seen after the anterior or inferior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: A child after a motor vehicle trauma is unable to abduct his arm. X-ray shows fracture around surgical neck humerus. Nerve likely to be injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve

 

Option B.

 

AXILLARY NERVE (C5-C6) INJURY

 

  • It is injured in fracture of surgical neck humerus, shoulder dislocation (anterior and inferior) and intramuscular injections.
  • Injury to the axillary nerve causes weakness in the shoulder abduction movement fro 15-90.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Musculocutaneous nerve. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Option C. Radial nerve. Common causes of radial nerve injuries are fractures of the humerus (spiral fracture along the distal third of the humerus (Holstein-Lewis fracture)), improper use of crutches, overuse of the arm (secondary to manual labor, chronic overuse, or sport-related participation), and work-related accidents. A patient may complain of decreased or absent sensation on the dorsoradial side of hand and wrist with an inability to extend wrist, thumb, and fingers. This is also referred to as "wrist drop.” If damaged at the axilla, there will be a loss of extension of the forearm, hand, and fingers. There will be a sensory loss in the lateral arm and posterior aspect of the forearm, radiating to the radial aspect of the dorsal hand and digits. This is seen commonly with "Saturday night palsy" and improperly using crutches (crutch palsy).

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. Repetitive elbow flexion and extension, arthritic changes, and valgus deformities at the elbow increase its vulnerability to injury. The patient may have numbness and paresthesia, radiating distally to the ulnar aspect of the hand, the fifth digit and the ulnar aspect of the fourth digit. It is usually associated with elbow flexion, particularly at night. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to the fracture of the surgical neck of humerus, the most commonly affected nerve is the axillary nerve.
  • Injury to the axillary nerve causes weakness of shoulder abduction movement up to 90.

choices.text: Axillary nerve injury
Suprascapular nerve injury
Erb’s palsy injury

questions.text: A 21-year male with fracture surgical neck humerus presented with regimental badge sign and difficulty in abduction. Nerve most likely to be injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary nerve injury

 

Option A.

 

AXILLARY NERVE INJURY

 

  • Axillary nerve is injured in fracture of surgical neck humerus, shoulder dislocation (anterior and inferior) and intramuscular injections.
  • Motor involvement:
    • Deltoid muscle palsy
    • Loss of rounded contour of shoulder, giving shoulder a flattened appearance and produce hollow inferior to acromion
  • Sensory involvement:
    • Lateral cutaneous nerve of arm
    • Sensory loss over lower half of deltoid (regimental badge area).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Suprascapular nerve injury. Suprascapular nerve can be injured in scapulothoracic dyskinesia, scapula/clavicle/proximal humerus fracture, glenohumeral joint dislocation and AC joint injuries. Patients usually present with dull, aching pain in the superior or posterolateral shoulder (or both) that can radiate down the arm or into the neck. Additional symptoms include a sense of instability if there is associated shoulder pathology, such as a labral or rotator cuff tear. The patient’s pain may be exacerbated by cross-body adduction and internal rotation. Weakness may be noted with either or both shoulder external rotation and abduction.

 

Option C. Erb’s palsy injury. Erb’s palsy is caused due to excessive downward stretching of shoulder on same side and head toward opposite side, e.g. Blow or fall on shoulder/delivery. As a result, the arm is adducted and medially rotated and the forearm is extended and pronated. The arm hangs limply by the side. There is loss of shoulder abduction and lateral rotation, elbow flexion, and forearm supination.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to a fracture of surgical neck of humerus, there occurs an injury to the axillary nerve.
  • Injury to the axillary nerve presents with difficulty in shoulder abduction movement.
  • There is presence of a regimental badge area around the deltoid on the arm that represents the loss of sensation in the lower half of the deltoid.

choices.text: Fracture proximal humerus
Improper use of crutch

questions.text: Axillary Nerve Injury is least likely in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Improper use of crutch

 

Option D.

 

AXILLARY NERVE INJURY

 

  • Axillary nerve is most commonly injured due to anterior/inferior shoulder dislocation, proximal humerus/surgical neck of humerus fracture, and intramuscular injections.
  • Improper use of crutches leads to radial nerve injury. This is known as Crutch palsy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Axillary nerve injury is least likely to be caused from improper use of crutches.
  • Crutch use causes radial nerve palsy, also called crutch palsy.

choices.text: Deltoid muscle is wasted
Extension of shoulder with arm abducted to 90 degrees is impossible
Small area of numbness is present over the shoulder region
Patient cannot initiate abduction

questions.text: In axillary nerve paralysis, all of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patient cannot initiate abduction

 

Option D.

 

AXILLARY NERVE INJURY

 

  • Motor involvement:
    • Deltoid muscle palsy
    • Loss of rounded contour of shoulder, giving shoulder a flattened appearance and produce hollow inferior to acromion
    • Weakness of abduction – 15- 90°
    • Initiation of Abduction of Shoulder is difficult
  • Up to 15° of shoulder abduction is done by the Supraspinatus muscle supplied by the Suprascapular Nerve (C5-C6).
  • From 15° to 90°, abduction is done by Deltoid muscle, supplied by the Axillary nerve (C5-C6).
  • Overhead abduction (>90°) is done by the Serratus anterior muscle (Nerve supply – Long thoracic nerve or Nerve of Bells – C5, C6, C7), and Trapezius muscle (supplied by Spinal part of accessory nerve)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deltoid muscle is wasted. True. Axillary nerve injury causes deltoid muscle palsy. This leads to weakness of the shoulder abduction in the range of 15-90.

 

Option B. Extension of shoulder with arm abducted to 90 degrees is impossible. True. Since the abduction of shoulder is not possible, there will be no extension of the shoulder also.

 

Option C. Small area of numbness is present over the shoulder region. True. A small area of numbness is present over the lower half of the deltoid. This is called regimental badge area.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to the axillary nerve paralysis, there is wasting of the deltoid muscle, leading to weakness of the shoulder abduction movement.
  • The patient is unable to initiate shoulder abduction and perform abduction till 90.
  • There is also an area of sensory loss in the lower half of the deltoid, called regimental badge area.

choices.text: Sensation on tapping the nerve
Numbness in the region of the nerve of inflating the pneumatic cuff
Tingling on flexion of the joint

questions.text: Tinel’s sign is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensation on tapping the nerve

 

Option A.

 

TINEL’S SIGN

 

  • Records regeneration rate by tapping on the nerve course from distal to proximal direction.
  • Tingling is felt at the sprouting nerve ends till the distal course of the nerve (Law of projection) and it disappears as myelinization takes place.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Numbness in the region of the nerve of inflating the pneumatic cuff. The described test might be related to assessing nerve compression or ischemia, such as in a Tourniquet test.

 

Option C. Tingling on flexion of the joint. Tinel's sign is specifically related to tapping or percussing over a nerve to elicit tingling, not related to joint flexion.

 

Option D. Applying direct pressure. Tinel's sign involves tapping or lightly percussing a nerve, not applying direct pressure.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel’s sign is the tingling sensation felt on tapping the nerve in the distal to proximal direction.

choices.text: Loss of rounded contour of shoulder
Loss of sensation along lateral side of upper arm
Loss of overhead abduction
Atrophy of deltoid muscle

questions.text: All of the following features can be observed after the injury to axillary nerve, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of overhead abduction

 

Option C.

 

ABDUCTION OF SHOULDER

 

  • Up to 15°: Supraspinatus muscle – Suprascapular Nerve (C5-C6)
  • 15 to 90°: Deltoid muscle – Axillary nerve (C5-C6)
  • Overhead abduction (>90°):
    • Serratus anterior muscle – Long thoracic nerve or Nerve of Bells (C5, C6, C7)
    • Trapezius muscle – Spinal part of accessory nerve
  • Axillary nerve supplies deltoid which is responsible for shoulder abduction of 15° to 90°; so, injury to axillary nerve would not affect overhead abduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Loss of rounded contour of shoulder. True. Due to axillary nerve injury, there is weakness of the deltoid muscle which leads to flattening of the rounded shoulder contour.

 

Option B. Loss of sensation along lateral side of upper arm. True. Axillary nerve injury causes loss of sensation over the lower half of the deltoid, called as regimental badge area.

 

Option D. Atrophy of deltoid muscle. True. Due to the weakness of the deltoid muscle, there is wasting/atrophy of the muscle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The overhead abduction of the shoulder is performed by the serratus anterior and trapezius muscles which are supplied by the long thoracic and spinal accessory nerves respectively.
  • Since these muscles are not affected by the axillary nerve injury, the overhead abduction of the shoulder is not lost.
  • 15-90 of shoulder abduction is lost in the axillary nerve injury.

choices.text: Posterior Interosseous nerve

questions.text: Image of dorsum of hand is given. Which nerve gives sensory supply to this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

Option B.

 

RADIAL NERVE

 

  • The radial nerve stems from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the upper limb.
  • It also supplies the triceps muscle of the arm, the muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm i.e., the extensors, the wrist joint capsule, and aspects of the dorsal skin of the forearm and hand.
  • The radial nerve proper innervates:
    • Triceps: forearm extension
    • Anconeus: elbow extension
    • Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL): wrist extension
    • Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB): wrist extension and abduction
    • Brachioradialis: elbow flexion and forearm pronation and supination, depending on the forearm's position
  • The radial nerve divides into a deep (mostly motor) branch, which becomes the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), and a superficial branch.
  • The PIN innervates:
    • Extensor digitorum: extension of the medial 4 hand digits
    • Supinator muscle: forearm supination
    • Extensor digiti minimi (EDM): 5th digit and wrist extension
    • Extensor carpi ulnaris (ECU): wrist extension and adduction
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL): thumb abduction at the wrist
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL): extension of the thumb's terminal phalanx
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB): thumb extension and abduction at the carpometacarpal and metacarpophalangeal joints
    • Extensor indicis proprius (EIP): index finger and wrist extension 
  • Sensory innervation includes:
    • Anterior aspect:
      • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: anterior lateral aspect of the mid-arm
    • Posterior aspect:
      • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: posterior distal arm
      • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: a strip on the posterior aspect of the forearm
      • Superficial branch: posterior aspect of the lateral 3½ digits and dorsal hand area

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior interosseous nerve. It is the superficial branch of the radial nerve. It gives motor innervation to the common extensors (ECRB, EDC, EDM, and ECU) and deep extensors (Supinator, APL, EPB, EPL, and EIP), and sensory innervation to dorsal wrist capsule.

 

Option C. Median nerve. It originates from the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus. It gives motor innervation to the superficial volar forearm group (pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus), intermediate group (FDS), deep group (lateral FDP, FPL, pronator quadratus), and hand (1-2 lumbricals, opponens pollicis, APB, flexor pollicis brevis). The cutaneous innervation by the median nerve is given to the hand (lateral aspect of palm, palmar surface, lateral 3 ½ digits) via palmar and digital cutaneous branches.

 

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. It is the continuation of medial cord of the brachial plexus. It gives motor innervation to the anterior compartment of the forearm, and hand. In the forearm, it supplies the FCU and medial FDP. In the hand, it supplies the hypothenar muscles, medial 2 lumbricals, adductor pollicis, palmar and dorsal interossei of hand. The sensory supply is to the medial half of the palm via palmar cutaneous branch, dorsal surface of medial 1 ½ fingers via dorsal cutaneous branch, and palmar surface of medial 1 ½ fingers via superficial branch.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image of the dorsum of hand in the question shows the sensory supply of the radial nerve to the hand.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on thenar eminence
Loss of sensation on hypothenar eminence
Atrophy of adductor pollicis

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of sensations in the lateral three and a half fingers. Which of the following will be an additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Opponens paralysis

 

Option D.

 

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY AT WRIST

 

  • Loss of opposition due to the paralysis of the thenar muscles with associated wasting of the thenar muscles.
  • The thumb is usually rotated and adducted and referred to as an "ape-like hand."

 

 

  • Sensory loss in lateral 3½ of digits and 2/3rd palm (autonomous zone is tip of index and middle finger).
  • The area of the skin in median nerve injury can experience sensory loss, where the skin is warm and dry.
  • In the case of long-standing vasomotor changes, the pulp of the fingers undergoes atrophic changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Loss of sensation on thenar eminence. The thenar eminence is is innervated primarily by the median nerve. In the scenario described, the involvement of the median nerve is unlikely, as it primarily innervates the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and half of the ring finger. Therefore, loss of sensation on the thenar eminence would not typically be an additional finding in this patient.

 

Option B. Loss of sensation on hypothenar eminence. The hypothenar eminence is innervated primarily by the ulnar nerve. Since the scenario describes loss of sensation in the lateral three and a half fingers, which are primarily innervated by the median nerve, there cannot be loss of sensation on the hypothenar eminence.

 

Option C. Atrophy of adductor pollicis. The adductor pollicis muscle of the hand is primarily innervated by the ulnar nerve. Atrophy of the adductor pollicis is a characteristic finding in ulnar nerve injury or compression. Therefore, atrophy of the adductor pollicis cannot be an additional finding in this patient.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presented case scenario describes loss of sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers, which is caused due to median nerve injury at the wrist.
  • When the median nerve is injured at the wrist, there is also loss of opposition of the thumb seen due to the paralysis of the opponens pollicis muscle.
  • This muscle paralysis appears as the ape-thumb deformity where the thumb remains in the same plane as the palm.

choices.text: Nerve entrapped in closed space
Muscle entrapped in closed space
Vein entrapped in closed space
Artery entrapped in closed space

questions.text: Compression neuropathy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve entrapped in closed space

 

Option A:

 

COMPRESSION NEUROPATHY

 

  • A compression neuropathy is caused when a peripheral nerve becomes compressed by surrounding tissues.
  • This can cause neuropathic/neurogenic pain that can be either acute or chronic in nature.
  • It occurs as a result of swelling of the surrounding tissues, or anatomical abnormalities.
  • Compression neuropathies occur within peripheral nerves and is typically characterized by pain and/or loss of function (motor and/or sensory) of the nerves as a result of chronic compression.
  • The most common types of nerve entrapments include:
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS): median nerve
    • Cubital tunnel syndrome: ulnar nerve
    • Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS)
    • Suprascapular nerve
    • Obtuator nerve of the groin area
    • Tarsal tunnel syndrome: posterior tibial nerve
    • Interdigit nerves, particularly between the 3rd and 4th toes, known as Morton's Neuroma.
    • The muscular arcade of the supinator (also known as the arcade of Frohse)
    • Posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) of the forearm
  • Chronic mild irritation of a nerve can result in an increase in neural tension.
  • Damage or compression of the neural structures often accompany joint or muscle injuries. 
  • Etiology:
    • Nerve entrapment syndromes can result from a chronic injury to a nerve as it travels through an osseoligamentous tunnel; the compression is typically between the ligamentous canal and adjacent bony surfaces.
    • In cases of nerve entrapment, at least one portion of the compressive surface is mobile. This results in either a repetitive "slapping" insult or a "rubbing/sliding" compression against sharp or tight edges, with motion at the adjacent joint, resulting in a chronic injury.
    • Entrapment neuropathies can also be caused by systemic disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, acromegaly, or hypothyroidism. 
  • Symptoms:
    • Localized or referred pain
    • Numbness, tingling
    • Paresthesia
    • Burning sensation
    • Impaired movement of affected body part
    • Muscle weakness
    • Muscle wasting
    • Dry thin skin - chronic cases

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Muscle entrapped in closed space. Muscle entrapment in a closed space is commonly referred to as compartment syndrome. This condition occurs when there is increased pressure within a muscle compartment, leading to reduced blood flow, nerve compression, and tissue damage. Compartment syndrome can be acute or chronic and typically requires medical intervention, including surgical decompression in severe cases. Symptoms may include severe pain, swelling, numbness, and weakness in the affected muscle compartment.

 

Option C: Vein entrapped in closed space. Vein entrapment in a closed space is often referred to as venous entrapment syndrome or May-Thurner syndrome. This condition occurs when the left iliac vein becomes compressed by the right iliac artery against the lumbar spine, leading to narrowing or obstruction of the vein. As a result, blood flow may be impeded, potentially causing symptoms such as swelling, pain, and discomfort in the affected area. Venous entrapment syndrome typically requires medical evaluation and may be treated with interventions such as anticoagulant therapy or surgery to relieve the compression on the vein.

 

Option D: Artery entrapped in closed space. Artery entrapment in a closed space is commonly referred to as arterial entrapment syndrome or arterial compression syndrome. This condition occurs when an artery becomes compressed or trapped within surrounding structures, such as muscles, ligaments, or bones. As a result, blood flow through the artery may be restricted, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected limb. Arterial entrapment syndrome typically requires medical evaluation and may be managed with interventions such as surgical release of the entrapped artery or vascular reconstruction to restore normal blood flow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Compression neuropathy refers to entrapment of the nerves in a closed space.
  • This commonly occurs in the peripheral nerves that are compressed by the surrounding tissues.

questions.text: In Brachial plexus injury with Horner’s syndrome, nerve root level involved is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T1

 

Option D.

 

KLUMPKE’S PALSY

 

  • T1 is involved in preganglionic lesion of lower trunk or pan brachial plexopathy.
  • Klumpke’s palsy is lower plexus injury.
  • C8 and T1 nerve roots are involved.
  • It is much less common, but more severe.
  • Wrist and finger flexors are weak and the intrinsic hand muscles are paralyzed.
  • Sensation is lost in ulnar forearm and there may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The brachial plexus injury with Horner’s syndrome is the Klumpke’s palsy which is caused due to involvement of the C8-T1 nerve root.

questions.text: Saturday night palsy is which type of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuropraxia

 

Option A.

 

SATURDAY NIGHT PALSY

 

  • Saturday night palsy is compressive neuropathy or neuropraxia or pressure palsy of the radial nerve in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object.
  • The onset of symptoms may take several days following the initial insult, resulting in a delayed presentation.
  • Numbness, weakness, tingling, pain, or any combination of these symptoms may be reported by patients.
  • Physical examination may reveal a characteristic wrist drop caused by the loss of extensor muscle function controlled by the radial nerve branches and the preservation of flexor muscle function supplied by other nerves in the hand and arm. As a result, the wrist and fingers cannot be extended at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The ability to extend the thumb is also lost, which makes it difficult to open the hand and grasp objects.
  • The triceps reflex, which is controlled by radial nerve innervation, may also be lost in patients.
  • Sensory deficits commonly affect the posterior or lateral upper arm, with symptoms distributing distally to affect the posterior forearm, posterior hand, and posterolateral aspect of the lateral three and a half digits.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Axonotmesis. This is seen in closed fractures and dislocations.

 

Option C. Neurotmesis. This involves injury from sharp objects like glass, knife or sharp metal.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Saturday night palsy is neuropraxia of the radial nerve.

choices.text: Superficial peroneal nerve
Deep peroneal nerve

questions.text: Foot drop is due to palsy of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deep peroneal nerve

 

Option B.

 

FOOT DROP

 

  • The Peroneal Nerve which is also called Common Fibular Nerve, is one of the two terminal branches of Sciatic nerve (L4-5, S1-3).
  • It descends laterally in the popliteal fossa at the back of the knee.
  • Within popliteal fossa, it divides into two terminal branches: the deep peroneal nerve and the superficial peroneal nerve.
  • Deep peroneal nerve courses anteriorly, between the two heads of peroneus longus muscle, continue down the leg, crossing the anterior compartment of the leg, provides motor innervation to the muscles involved in dorsiflexion of the foot and toe extension.
  • It also supplies the skin between the 1st and the 2nd toes.
  • Injury to deep peroneal nerve leads to inability to dorsiflex the foot – FOOT DROP.
  • Superficial peroneal nerve courses along the lateral aspect of the leg and provides sensory innervation to the anterior and lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • It doesn’t provide any motor innervation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: Ankle sprains and ankle twisting cause stretching of superficial peroneal nerve. It can compress at the exit in the deep fascia of the leg. This stretching/compression may present as pain and paresthesias over dorsum of foot. Direct damage from fractures of the proximal fibula, perforating injury to lateral leg may present as loss of eversion, and loss of sensation over most of dorsal foot and anterolateral aspect of distal leg.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve neuropathy: Is an uncommon peripheral neuropathy, which most commonly occurs when the femoral nerve is compressed as it passes under the inguinal ligament, anterior to the iliopsoas muscle. The patient presents with groin pain, loss of power of hip flexion and knee extension, loss of/reduced knee jerk, decreased sensation over anteromedial thigh and medial aspect of the lower leg, and loss of muscle bulk of quadriceps.

 

Option D. Obturator nerve: Obturator neuropathy is a difficult clinical problem to evaluate. One possible cause of pain is due to fascial entrapment of the nerve. Symptoms include medial thigh or groin pain, weakness with leg adduction, and sensory loss in the medial thigh of the affected side.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Foot drop is caused due to injury to the deep peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve.

choices.text: Flexor carpi ulnaris

questions.text: Tendon most commonly used for tendon transfer is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palmaris longus

 

Option A.

 

TENDON TRANSFER

 

  • Common tendon transfers for radial nerve palsy include pronator teres (PT) to extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) to restore wrist extension, flexor carpi radialis (FCR) to extensor digitorum communis (EDC) to restore finger extension, and palmaris longus (PL) to extensor pollicis longus (EPL) to restore thumb extension.
  • Remember, it can be absent in 15% of patients.
  • If the PL is not present, the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendon of the long finger is used to restore thumb and index finger extension. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most commonly used tendon for tendon transfer is the palmaris longus.
  • If palmaris longus is absent, then flexor digitorum superficialis tendon is used.

questions.text: Test for tight iliotibial band is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ober’s test

 

Option A:

 

OBER’S TEST

 

  • The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB).
  • The other tests used for tight IT band are Noble’s test and the Renne test.
  • The patient is placed in side-lying with the affected side up.
  • Bottom knee and hip are flexed to flatten the lumbar curve.
  • The examiner stands behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis above the gluteal muscles.
  • Grasping the distal end of the patient’s affected leg, flex the leg to a right angle at the knee.
  • Then, extend and abduct the hip joint.
  • Slowly lower the leg towards the table i.e., perform the hip adduction until the motion is restricted.
  • Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized.
  • If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly and the patient won't experience pain; in this case, the test is negative.
  • If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted and the test is positive.
  • If patient reports knee pain, stop the test and perform the modified ober test.
  • The lateral knee pain could be caused from the ITB attachment to Gerdy's tubercle.
  • Medial knee pain could be caused by strain from the Ober test.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Thomas test. The Thomas Test measures hip flexor length and distinguishes tightness between one joint and two joint muscles. Hip flexor length directly correlates to the available range of motion at the hip and knee joints.

 

Option C: Simmond’s test. Simmonds-Thompson test is a diagnostic tool for Achilles tendon rupture. The absence of foot plantarflexion on calf compression is interpreted as a positive test result and indicative of Achilles tendon rupture.

 

Option D: Charnley’s test. Charnley's test, also known as the Charnley compression test, is a clinical maneuver used to assess the stability and integrity of the hip joint, particularly in cases of suspected hip pathology such as hip osteoarthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To test the tightness of the iliotibial band, the Ober’s test is used.
  • The Thomas test is used to test the tightness of the hip flexor muscles.
  • The Simmond’s test is used to evaluate the Achilles tendon rupture.
  • The Charnley’s test is used to evaluate for hip osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A patient can make his fist but is unable to flex his index finger. Which nerve is affected in him?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Median nerve

 

Option D.

 

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Due to injury of the median nerve at the elbow, flexion of interphalangeal joints of index and middle fingers is lost, so there is pointing index or positive Ochsner clasp or Benediction test.

 

 

 

a. Pointing index; b. Benediction test

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve. With the hand supinated, the extensors are aided by gravity, and the hand function may appear normal. However, when the hand is pronated, the wrist and hand will drop. This is also referred to as "wrist drop.”

 

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. The initial presentation include a decrease in normal hand function. The MCP joints is hyperextended, and the IP joints flexed. This is called ulnar claw hand. The second and third digits will not be as involved as the fourth and fifth digits. This is because the median nerve innervates the lumbricals involving the second and third digits, and the ulnar nerve innervates the lumbricals involving the fourth and fifth digits. The patient may also exhibit functional weakness while attempting a grasp, grip, or pinch.

 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve. Isolated injury to the musculocutaneous nerve is a rare occurrence. Associated signs and symptoms of an isolated musculocutaneous neuropathy may include weakness in elbow flexion or shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and pain or paresthesia at the lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The inability to flex the index finger and make a fist are suggestive of median nerve injury at the elbow.
  • This occurs due to loss of flexion of IP joint of the middle and index fingers, presenting as a pointing index deformity.

choices.text: Deep branch of ulnar nerve
Superficial branch of ulnar nerve
Ulnar nerve before division into deep and superficial

questions.text: A patient present with loss of sensation of ring and little fingers with wasting of hypothenar muscles. Where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve before division into deep and superficial

 

Option C.

 

ULNAR NERVE (C8, T1)

 

  • The Ulnar nerve is derived in most instances exclusively from the C8, T1 nerve roots although sometimes there is a minor C7 component.
  • Nearly all ulnar fibers arise in the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and pass through the medial cord, the terminal extension of which is the ulnar nerve.
  • It is worth remembering that a large portion of the median nerve and the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve also arises from the medial cord.
  • The ulnar nerve runs down the medial aspect of the arm, and there are no significant branches in the arm.
  • At the elbow, the nerve passes into the groove between the medial epicondyle and olecranon process, the ulnar groove.
  • Just beyond the groove, the nerve runs under a tendinous arch formed by the two heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle.
  • This arch is commonly referred to as the cubital tunnel but is more correctly called the humeral-ulnar aponeurosis (HUA).
  • Muscular branches to the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle and the ulnar portion of flexor digitorum profundus are found at this site.
  • The ulnar nerve then passes down the medial forearm with the next important branch being the dorsal cutaneous sensory branch just proximal to the wrist.
  • This nerve supplies sensation to the dorsal medial hand and digits, whilst at the ulnar styloid, there is a palmar cutaneous branch that supplies the palmar aspect of the hand.
  • Finally, the ulnar nerve passes into the hand through Guyon’s canal.
  • The ulnar nerve and artery pass superficial to the flexor retinaculum, via the ulnar canal.
  • The course of the ulnar nerve through the wrist contrasts with that of the median nerve, which travels deep to the flexor retinaculum of the hand and therefore, through the carpal tunnel.
  • Here, it gives off the following branches:
    • Superficial branch of ulnar nerve
    • Deep branch of ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve deep branch supplies:
    • At its origin, it supplies the hypothenar muscles.
    • As it crosses the deep part of the hand, it supplies all the interosseous muscles and the third and fourth lumbricals.
    • It ends by supplying the adductor pollicis and the medial (deep) head of the flexor pollicis brevis.
    • It also sends articular filaments to the wrist-joint.
    • The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve is a terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.
    • It supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand, and divides into a proper palmar digital nerve and a common palmar digital nerve.
    • In the question above, since sensory loss and hypothenar wasting is seen, hence it involves whole ulnar nerve before division.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep branch of ulnar nerve. The deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, including the interossei muscles, but it does not provide sensory innervation to the skin. Therefore, a lesion affecting only the deep branch of the ulnar nerve would not lead to loss of sensation in the ring and little fingers.

 

Option B. Superficial branch of ulnar nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the skin of the ulnar aspect of the hand, including the ring and little fingers. However, it does not innervate the hypothenar muscles. Therefore, a lesion affecting only the superficial branch would not lead to wasting of the hypothenar muscles.

 

Option D. Median nerve. The median nerve primarily innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm and muscles in the thenar eminence of the hand. It also provides sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the hand, but it does not innervate the ring and little fingers or the hypothenar muscles. Therefore, a lesion of the median nerve would not cause the specific symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The loss of sensation of the ring and little fingers and wasting of the hypothenar muscles are descriptive of lesion of the ulnar nerve before its division into the deep and superficial branches at the wrist.

choices.text: Palmar branch of median nerve
Palmar branch of ulnar nerve

questions.text: Nail bed of index finger is supplied by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

Option A.

 

MEDIAN NERVE

 

  • The median nerve predominantly provides motor innervation to the flexor muscles of the forearm and hand.
  • The median nerve also provides sensory innervation to the dorsal aspect (nail bed) of the distal first two digits of the hand, the palmar aspect of the thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger, the palm, as well as the medial aspect of the forearm.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve provides motor innervation to part of the forearm and majority of the hand. It supplies sensory cutaneous innervation to the medial forearm, medial wrist, and medial one and one-half digits. 

 

Option C. Palmar branch of median nerve. It pierces the palmar carpal ligament, and divides into lateral and medial branches. The lateral branch supplies the skin over the ball of the thumb. The medial branch supplies the skin of the palm.

 

Option D. Palmar branch of ulnar nerve. The palmar branch of ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep branches. The superficial branch supplies the Palmaris brevis, and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand. The deep branch supplies the three short muscles of the little finger, all the Interossei and the third and fourth Lumbricals: the Adductor pollicis and the medial head of the Flexor pollicis brevis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The nail bed of the index finger is supplied by the median nerve.

choices.text: Dislocation of elbow

questions.text: Commonest cause of “Wrist Drop” is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fracture humerus

 

Option B)

 

WRIST DROP

 

  • The most common cause of wrist drop is the radial nerve injury.
  • The radial nerve is most commonly injured by the humerus shaft fractures.
  • These are commonly spiral fractures between the middle and distal thirds of the humeral shaft.
  • A spiral fracture in the distal third followed by proximal and radial displacement of the distal bone fragment is also known as a Holstein-Lewis fracture.
  • In the distal third of the arm, the radial nerve lies directly over the periosteum with no interposed muscle.
  • Here, the nerve also has restricted mobility as it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum.
  • The radial nerve is most susceptible to injury in the distal one-third of the arm.
  • It can be compressed between the overlapping bone fragments leading to entrapment neuropathy.
  • Loss of forearm extension can occur when the radial nerve is injured in the axilla.
  • Injury to the nerve in the arm does not significantly impact the triceps and the anconeus, therefore the ability to extend the forearm remains intact.
  • Motor deficits include loss of mobility in the brachioradialis and supinator muscle, which supinate the forearm, as well as loss of mobility in the extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis, which extends the wrist.
  • This presents as a classical wrist drop deformity.
  • An inability to extend the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints may also result.
  • Extension of the interphalangeal joints remains intact as the lumbricals and interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • The sensory deficits include loss of sensation in the posterior forearm, dorsum of the hand and lateral 3 ½ fingers.
  • Sensation in the posterior arm remains intact as it is innervated by the radial nerve before it reaches the diaphysis of the humerus.
  • These signs are often accompanied with pain, tingling, and numbness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intramuscular injection. A delayed complication of intramuscular injections is the axillary nerve injury that presents as the weakness of the shoulder abduction from 15-90.

 

Option C. Dislocation of elbow. Posterior dislocation of the elbow can injure the ulnar or median nerves. This may present as ulnar claw hand or ape thumb deformities of the hand.

 

Option D. Dislocation of shoulder. Whilst all nerves of the brachial plexus are at risk of injury during glenohumeral dislocation, the most commonly injured is the axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The commonest cause of wrist drop deformity of the hand is the fracture of the shaft of the humerus, which causes radial nerve injury and the consequent deformity.

choices.text: Caused by shoulder dislocation

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Late onset

 

Option B.

 

TARDY ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Occurs in association with cubitus valgus, ulnar nerve gets stretched slowly.
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a chronic clinical condition characterized by a delayed onset ulnar neuropathy after an injury to the elbow.
  • Typically, tardy ulnar nerve palsy occurs as a consequence of nonunion of pediatric lateral condyle fractures at the elbow, which eventually lead to a cubitus valgus deformity.
  • While the child grows, the deformity worsens and the ulnar nerve is gradually stretched until classic symptoms of ulnar nerve neuropathy appear.
  • Other childhood elbow trauma has also been associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy, including supracondylar fractures resulting in cubitus varus, fractures of the medial condyle and of the olecranon, as well as radial head or Monteggia fractures/dislocation, with or without deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late onset neuropathy of the ulnar nerve.
  • It is caused by lateral condyle humerus fracture in children.

choices.text: Shaft of tibia
Neck of fibula
Lower tibiofibular joint

questions.text: Common peroneal nerve is related to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck of fibula

 

Option B)

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is a major nerve that innervates the lower extremity.
  • It is one of the two major branches off the sciatic nerve and receives fibers from the posterior divisions of L4 through S2 nerve roots. 
  • The common peroneal nerve separates from the sciatic nerve in the distal posterior thigh proximal to the popliteal fossa.
  • After branching off of the sciatic nerve, it continues down the thigh, running posteroinferior to the biceps femoris muscle, and crosses laterally to the head of the lateral gastrocnemius muscle through the posterior intermuscular septum.
  • The nerve then curves around the fibular neck before dividing into two branches, the superficial peroneal nerve (SPN) and the deep peroneal nerve (DPN). 
  • The common peroneal nerve does not have any motor innervation before dividing; however, it provides sensory innervation to the lateral leg via the lateral sural nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. 
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve provides both motor and sensory innervation.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor: Lateral compartment – Peroneus longus, Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • The deep peroneal nerve also provides both motor and sensory innervation in the leg.
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation is as follows:
    • Motor: Anterior compartment – Tibialis anterior, Extensor hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus, Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal web space

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shaft of tibia. The shaft of the tibia is not directly related to the common peroneal nerve. The tibia is a separate bone from the fibula, and the common peroneal nerve primarily courses along the fibula.

 

Option C. Lower tibiofibular joint. Although the common peroneal nerve is in proximity to the lower tibiofibular joint, it does not have a direct anatomical relationship with this joint. The nerve primarily runs along the fibular neck and head.

 

Option D. Shaft of fibula. While the common peroneal nerve courses along the fibula, it typically does not relate directly to the shaft of the fibula. Instead, it primarily wraps around the neck and head of the fibula.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The common peroneal nerve runs along the neck of the fibula.
  • It curves around the neck of the fibula and then branches into superficial and deep branches.

choices.text: Patient has an injury to the median nerve
He should have also lost extension of the forearm
Patient has injured the radial nerve in the spiral groove
There is combined involvement of the radial nerve and median nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old carpenter with a blunt trauma to his arm sustained a fracture following which he developed wrist drop, loss of extension at fingers and loss of sensations on the lateral aspect of the wrist joint. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient has injured the radial nerve in the spiral groove

 

Option C)

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The radial nerve is prone to entrapment at three different sites: as it passes between the heads of the triceps brachii muscle, in the spiral groove of the humerus, and while piercing the lateral intermuscular septum.
  • In the distal third, it travels directly in the spiral groove of the humeral shaft.
  • The spiral groove is located between the lateral and posterior aspect of the humeral diaphysis. 
  • The spiral groove, also known as the radial groove is an important landmark in relation to the radial nerve in the arm.
  • Humeral shaft fractures are the leading cause of radial neuropathy in the arm.
  • These are commonly spiral fractures between the middle and distal thirds of the humeral shaft.
  • A spiral fracture in the distal third followed by proximal and radial displacement of the distal bone fragment is also known as a Holstein-Lewis fracture.
  • In the distal third of the arm, the radial nerve lies directly over the periosteum with no interposed muscle.
  • Here, the nerve also has restricted mobility as it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum.
  • The radial nerve is most susceptible to injury in the distal one-third of the arm.
  • Motor deficits include loss of mobility in the brachioradialis and supinator muscle, which supinate the forearm, as well as loss of mobility in the extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis, which extends the wrist.
  • An inability to extend the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints may also result.
  • Extension of the interphalangeal joints remains intact as the lumbricals and interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • The sensory deficits include loss of sensation in the posterior forearm, dorsum of the hand and lateral 3 ½ fingers.
  • Sensation in the posterior arm remains intact as it is innervated by the radial nerve before it reaches the diaphysis of the humerus.
