  • These signs are often accompanied with pain, tingling, and numbness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patient has an injury to the median nerve. False. In the given scenario, the patient sustained blunt trauma followed by fracture which caused wrist drop, loss of finger extension and sensations on lateral aspect of wrist joint. The median nerve can also be injured from blunt trauma or compression neuropathy. The motor symptoms includes loss of ability to abduct and oppose the thumb (ape thumb deformity), weak forearm pronation, and wrist and finger flexion. Sensory loss appears in the thumb, index finger, middle finger and radial aspect of the ring finger.

 

Option B. He should also lost extension of the forearm. False. Loss of extension of the forearm typically occurs when there is involvement of the radial nerve at a higher level in the arm, such as in the axilla or proximal to the elbow. Injuries to the radial nerve at higher levels can affect the triceps muscle, which is responsible for extending the forearm at the elbow joint. Therefore, patients commonly present with weakness or paralysis of forearm extension in addition to wrist drop. However, in the scenario provided, the patient's symptoms are consistent with a radial nerve injury in the spiral groove of the humerus, which primarily affects the wrist extensor muscles and sensation in the dorsal aspect of the hand and lateral aspect of the wrist joint. Injuries at this level typically spare the triceps muscle, preserving forearm extension.

 

Option D. There is combined involvement of the radial nerve and median nerve. False. While it is possible to sustain injuries to multiple nerves simultaneously, such as in cases of complex trauma or nerve compression syndromes, the symptoms described in the scenario are more consistent with isolated radial nerve injury. There is no mention of symptoms that would suggest median nerve involvement, such as weakness in thumb opposition or flexion of the wrist and fingers.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, there is history of blunt trauma to the arm causing fracture with wrist drop, loss of finger extension, and loss of sensation on lateral aspect of wrist.
  • These symptoms are suggestive of radial nerve injury at the spiral/radial groove of the humerus due to the fracture of the humerus shaft from the trauma.

choices.text: Common peroneal nerve

questions.text: In a road traffic accident, a patient was lying in right lateral position with bruise on face, elbow and lateral side of knee. Which nerve injury has maximum chances in this position of the victim?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Common peroneal nerve

 

Option C)

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Amongst the mentioned nerves, most frequently injured nerve in lateral position will be the nerve that has maximum chances of injury due to compression against a bony prominence and that is common peroneal nerve near fibular neck.
  • The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, which innervates muscles in the lower leg and foot and provides sensation to the dorsum of the foot and toes.
  • The lateral side of the knee is in close proximity to where the common peroneal nerve passes around the fibular head, making it susceptible to injury during trauma, especially if there is a direct impact to the lateral aspect of the knee.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve. The trigeminal nerve primarily innervates the face, providing sensory information for the forehead, cheeks, and jaw. However, the bruises on the face may not necessarily indicate trigeminal nerve injury, as these bruises could be due to impact trauma without direct nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve innervates the muscles of the forearm and hand, providing sensation to the little finger and part of the ring finger. Bruising on the elbow may suggest injury in the vicinity of the ulnar nerve, but this position alone doesn't necessarily predispose the ulnar nerve to maximum chances of injury.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve. The tibial nerve is also a branch of the sciatic nerve and innervates the muscles in the posterior compartment of the lower leg and foot. It provides sensation to the sole of the foot. While it's possible for the tibial nerve to be injured in a road traffic accident, the described bruising locations are not typically associated with the area innervated by the tibial nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Given the scenario and the positioning of the bruises, Common peroneal nerve injury is the most likely nerve injury.
  • The lateral side of the knee is a common location for injury to this nerve due to its superficial course around the fibular head, making it prone to compression or trauma in accidents involving lateral knee impact.

questions.text: Carpal tunnel syndrome is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smith’s fracture

 

Option D)

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Etiology:
  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders – Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, sarcoidosis.
  • Injury related – Synovitis of tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle’s fracture)

 

 

  • Smith's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with the distal fragment displaced anteriorly.
  • Like Colles' fracture, it doesn't directly cause carpal tunnel syndrome, but similar to Colles' fracture, the subsequent complications such as malunion or altered wrist anatomy may contribute to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pregnancy. During pregnancy, hormones cause fluid retention, and softens the ligament that forms the roof of the tunnel. When this happens, the nerve running through the tunnel may become squashed which can cause symptoms like pins and needles, numbness and stiff painful hands.

 

Option B. Alcoholism. Chronic alcoholism can lead to various neurological conditions. Alcohol drinking is related to the potential risk of development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Colles’ fracture. Colles' fracture is a type of fracture of the distal radius bone in the forearm. While Colles' fracture itself doesn't directly cause carpal tunnel syndrome, the subsequent immobilization or malunion of the fracture may lead to changes in the wrist anatomy or increased pressure on the median nerve, potentially predisposing to carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome is seen in pregnancy, alcoholism and as a complication of malunited Colles’ fracture.
  • It is not directly related to the Smith’s fracture.

questions.text: Cubital tunnel syndrome involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

Option B)

 

CUBITAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Cubital tunnel syndrome is neuropathy of the ulnar nerve causing numbness and shooting pain along the medial aspect of the forearm, also including the medial half of the fourth and the fifth digits.
  • It is caused by compression of the ulnar nerve at the elbow region. 
  • Stretching the ulnar nerve due to repeated elbow flexion activity can also result in similar symptoms.
  • The presenting complaint is "pins and needles" in the forearm and the hand.
  • The tingling sensation is present along the little finger and medial half of the ring finger. 
  • The symptoms are generally aggravated with elbow flexion.
  • These symptoms may be present transiently initially then gradually get worse.
  • On examination, findings may include a reduced or complete loss of sensation on the palmar and dorsal sides of the little finger and the medial part of the ring finger in advanced cases. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve. The median nerve is related to the carpal tunnel syndrome. It is caused by the compression of the nerve in the flexor retinaculum at the wrist.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve. The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and innervates muscles in the posterior compartment of the leg and the sole of the foot. It is not associated with cubital tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D. Common peroneal nerve. The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is not involved in cubital tunnel syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cubital tunnel syndrome involves the entrapment of the ulnar nerve at the elbow, leading to symptoms like tingling, numbness and weakness in the hand and 4th-5th digits.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for entrapment neuropathy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) EMG/NCV

 

Option D)

 

INVESTIGATIONS FOR ENTRAPMENT NEUROPATHY

 

  • Entrapment neuropathies are caused by compression and/or irritation of peripheral nerves as they travel through narrow anatomical spaces.
  • The most common entrapment neuropathy is carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) followed by cubital tunnel syndrome. 
  • Another common condition is “sciatica”.
  • EMG and NCV studies are considered as the investigation of choice for entrapment neruopathy.
  • Electromyography (EMG) measures the electrical activity of muscles in response to nerve stimulation, helping to assess nerve function.
  • Nerve conduction velocity (NCV) measures how fast electrical impulses travel through a nerve, which can indicate nerve damage or compression.
  • These tests can precisely localize nerve entrapment, determine its severity, and differentiate it from other neurological conditions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT scan. CT scans can provide detailed images of bone structures and some soft tissues. They are not typically used as the primary investigation for entrapment neuropathy. CT scans are more useful for assessing bony abnormalities or injuries but may not show nerve entrapment as clearly as other imaging modalities.

 

Option B. Clinical examination. Clinical examination is essential for diagnosing any medical condition, including entrapment neuropathy. However, while clinical examination can provide valuable information about symptoms, signs, and physical findings, it may not always pinpoint the exact location or severity of nerve entrapment. Therefore, it is usually supplemented by other diagnostic tests.

 

Option C. Ultrasonography. Ultrasonography can be useful in evaluating soft tissue structures, including nerves, tendons, and muscles. It is a non-invasive and relatively inexpensive imaging modality. While it can sometimes identify nerve entrapment, it may not always provide sufficient detail to confirm the diagnosis definitively.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of entrapment neuropathy are the EMG and NCV studies as they describe the precise location and severity of the entrapment of the nerve.

choices.text: Extensor carpi ulnaris
Abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presents with clumsiness of hand. His ulnar nerve is affected. Clumsiness is due to palsy of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interosseous muscle

 

Option D)

 

  • Clumsiness is due to paralysis of muscles which are involved in fine movement, i.e., interossei and lumbricals.
  • When the ulnar nerve is affected, it can lead to weakness or paralysis of the interosseous muscles, resulting in impaired finger movements and decreased grip strength.
  • This weakness can manifest as clumsiness in hand movements, making it difficult for the patient to perform tasks requiring precision and coordination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Extensor carpi ulnaris. The extensor carpi ulnaris muscle is located in the forearm and is responsible for extending and adducting the wrist. Although it is innervated by the ulnar nerve, palsy of this muscle typically results in weakness or inability to perform these movements, rather than causing clumsiness of the hand.

 

Option B. Abductor pollicis brevis. The abductor pollicis brevis muscle is located in the thenar eminence of the hand and is responsible for abducting the thumb at the carpometacarpal joint. It is innervated by the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve. Therefore, this muscle will not be involved in the scenario.

 

Option C. Opponens pollicis. The opponens pollicis muscle is located in the thenar eminence of the hand. Its main function is to oppose the thumb, bringing it towards the other fingers. Although it is innervated by the median nerve, it will not be affected in the given scenario.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The clumsiness of the hand occurs due to loss of fine movements of the hand and fingers.
  • The fine movements are controlled by the interossei of the hand.
  • Since, in the given case scenario, ulnar nerve is affected from leprosy, thus there will be an effect on the interossei, leading to clumsiness of the hand.

questions.text: For Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, test used is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phalen’s test

 

Option A)

 

PHALEN’S TEST

 

  • It is a Provocative Test for CTS.
  • The patient flexes both the elbows, allowing wrists to fall into maximum flexion.
  • The patient is asked to push the dorsal surface of hands together and hold this position for 30-60 seconds.
  • This position will increase the pressure in the carpal tunnel, in effect compressing the median nerve between the transverse carpal ligament and the anterior border of the distal end of the radius.
  • Positive test: When the patient's symptoms are reproduced, test gives the same symptoms as that experienced with carpal tunnel syndrome, namely paresthesia (burning, tingling, numbness) in the distribution of the median nerve. 
  • Negative test: Patient feels no pain or any other symptom, even if the motion is maintained for three minutes or longer.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Finkelstein test: It is done for De-Quervain tenosynovitis.

 

Option C. Cozen’s Test: It is done for Tennis Elbow.

 

Option D. Thompson Test: It is done to check integrity of Achilles Tendon.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The tests done for carpal tunnel syndrome includes:
    • Tinel’s sign
    • Phalen’s test
    • Reverse Phalen’s test
    • Durkan’s test

choices.text: Sensory loss over medial aspect of hand
Weakness of flexor carpi ulnaris

questions.text: Which of the following will not take place in a patient with ulnar nerve injury in arm?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thumb adduction

 

Option B.

 

ULNAR NERVE INJURY IN ARM

 

  • In a patient with ulnar nerve palsy, flexor carpi ulnaris will be paralyzed.
  • There will be sensory loss over medial aspect of hand (area supplied by ulnar nerve) and there will be claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic muscles of hand.
  • Adductor pollicis is supplied by ulnar nerve, hence in ulnar nerve palsy, thumb adduction will not be seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the ulnar nerve injury in the arm, there will be presentation of claw hand, sensory loss over medial aspect of hand, and weakness of the flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Weakness of the flexor carpi ulnaris will lead to weakness of the ulnar deviation and flexion of the wrist.
  • Thumb adduction will not take place as there will be paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.

choices.text: Flexor digitorum superficialis
Flexor digitorum profundus

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a substitute for wrist extensors in radial nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pronator teres

 

Option A)

 

TENDON TRANSFERS IN RADIAL NERVE PALSY

 

  • Jones Transfer—Most Important:
    • Pronator Teres to Extensor carpi radialis longus/Extensor carpi radialis brevis—Wrist extensors
    • Flexor carpi ulnaris to Extensor digitorum communis— Finger extensors
    • Flexor carpi radialis to Extensor pollicis longus (Extensor pollicis brevis and Abductor pollicis longus)— Thumb functions
  • Brand Transfer:
    • Pronator Teres to Extensor carpi radialis brevis
    • Flexor carpi radialis to Extensor digitorum longus
    • Palmaris longus to rerouted Extensor pollicis longus
  • Boyes Transfer:
    • Pronator Teres to Extensor carpi radialis longus/extensor carpi radialis brevis
    • Flexor carpi radialis to Extensor pollicis brevis and Abductor pollicis longus
    • Flexor digitorum superficialis Middle Finger to Extensor digitorum communis
    • Flexor digitorum superficialis Ring Finger to Extensor pollicis longus and extensor indicis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Palmaris longus. The palmaris longus is the most commonly used tendon for transfer/grafts. It is used for the substitution of extensor pollicis longus. But pronator teres is the preferred choice for wrist extensor substitution after radial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis. It is substituted for extensor digitorum communis in the middle finger, and extensor pollicis longus and extensor indicis in the ring finger.

 

Option D. Flexor digitorum profundus. The flexor digitorum profundus muscle is also located in the forearm and is responsible for flexing the distal phalanges of the fingers. Similar to the flexor digitorum superficialis, it primarily acts as a finger flexor and also assists in flexing the wrist. However, it does not directly extend the wrist and would not serve as a substitute for wrist extensors in radial nerve palsy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The primary substitute muscle used for wrist extensor in radial nerve palsy is the pronator teres muscle.

choices.text: Anterior interosseous nerve
Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Extension of metacarpophalangeal joint of the hand is lost in injury to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior interosseous nerve

 

Option D)

 

POSTERIOR INTEROSSEOUS NERVE INJURY

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve.
  • The radial nerve travels down the arm and divides into superficial and deep branches in the proximal forearm.  
  • Normally, the deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve.  
  • Anatomical variants include the deep radial nerve passing through the Arcade of Frohse to become the posterior interosseous nerve.
  • This variant can increase susceptibility to impingement. 
  • The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm.
  • The terminal branch of the posterior interosseous nerve travels distally into the floor of the 4th dorsal compartment of the wrist to innervate the dorsal wrist capsule.
  • Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm.
  • It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension.
  • However, there should be preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus.
  • The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension.
  • When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Motor function of the median nerve are mainly flexor aspect of forearm, hand, and thumb. It innervates all the superficial muscles on the front of the forearm except the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris.

 

Option B. UInar nerve. Weakness may start from clumsiness and loss of hand dexterity. This may then progress to a decrease in handgrip and pinch strength (Froment sign). In more severe cases, there may be atrophy of the hand intrinsic muscles and clawing of the fourth and the fifth digits, classically known as claw hand.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve. Anterior interosseous neuropathy is a form of median nerve injury. The anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve moves into the anterior forearm. It innervates the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and the deep flexors of 2nd and 3rd digits. There is no cutaneous branch; thus, the neuropathy presents with muscle weakness, and no sensory deficits. On physical examination, this can appear as the inability to approximate the thumb and index finger. Patients are unable to pinch objects or make an "OK" sign with their index finger and thumb.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Extension of the MCP joint of the hand is lost in the injury to the posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is involved in ‘pronator teres syndrome’?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

Option A)

 

PRONATOR TERES SYNDROME

 

  • Pronator teres syndrome (PTS) is caused by compression of the median nerve by the pronator teres muscle in the forearm.
  • Etiology:
    • Quick and repetitive grasping or pronation movements (prolonged hammering, cleaning dishes, tennis) may cause pronator teres muscle hypertrophy and entrapment of Median Nerve.
    •  Pronator teres syndrome has been described after local trauma, compression with Schwanomma, and in patients undergoing anticoagulation therapy and renal dialysis.  
    • Tight bicipital aponeurosis may also exacerbate the symptoms.
  • Pronator teres syndrome is a rare condition that may be easily overlooked and mistaken for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). 
  • Study reports shows a higher prevalence of pronator teres syndrome in men.
  • Pronator teres syndrome may manifest with pain in the volar forearm region, aggravated by resisted pronation of the forearm and flexion of the elbow, and a positive Tinel sign over the proximal edge of Pronator Teres.  
  • The patient may report significant weakness.
  • Wasting of the median nerve innervated muscles is rare, but a mild weakness of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) and abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is not uncommon, with some involvement of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) to digits 2 and 3 and opponens pollicis.
  • The Pronator Teres itself is usually spared because it receives innervation before the Median Nerve pierces it.
  • Sensory loss is variable, involving the palm of the hand or mimic that of carpal tunnel syndrome, including the thenar eminence, thumb, index, middle, and ring fingers.
  • A positive Phalen test over the Pronator Teres muscle can be present in 50% of cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The median nerve passes through the pronator teres muscle.
  • Compression of the nerve by this muscle leads to pronator teres syndrome, characterized by pain in volar forearm region, weakness and sensory loss in the palm.

choices.text: Extensor Pollicis Longus
Ulnar half of FDP

questions.text: “Ulnar paradox” is related with:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulnar half of FDP

 

Option D)

 

ULNAR PARADOX

 

  • Disability of the hand is maximum with a lesion of ulnar nerve at wrist (Low Ulnar Nerve).
  • In high ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar nerve injury at elbow), forearm muscles are involved and the clawing is less as compared to low ulnar nerve palsy. 
  • The flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) muscle is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.
  • The ulnar half of the FDP supplies the ring and little fingers.
  • The "ulnar paradox" refers to a condition where there is a loss of flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the ring and little fingers while attempting to make a fist.
  • This paradoxical loss of flexion occurs due to ulnar nerve dysfunction affecting the ulnar half of the FDP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lumbricals. The lumbrical muscles are small intrinsic muscles of the hand that arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) muscle. They flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints of the fingers. However, they are not directly associated with the "ulnar paradox."

 

Option B. Intrinsic muscle. Intrinsic muscles are responsible for fine motor movements and stability of the fingers. While ulnar nerve dysfunction can affect the intrinsic muscles of the hand, the term "ulnar paradox" specifically refers to a phenomenon related to the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) muscle.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus. The extensor pollicis longus muscle is located in the forearm and is responsible for extending the thumb at the interphalangeal joint. It is not directly related to the "ulnar paradox."

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ulnar paradox is related with the ulnar half of the FDP muscle, leading to inability of DIP joint flexion of the ring and little fingers.

questions.text: Action of lumbricals at this joint is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion

 

Option A.

 

ACTION OF LUMBRICALS

 

  • MCP joint is at level of distal palmar crease.
  • The lumbrical muscles are located deep in the palm.
  • These muscles originate from the FDP tendons and insert on the fingers' extensor expansions, which are connected to the proximal and middle phalanges.
  • Each finger attaches to 2 lumbricals, except for the thumb, which is associated only with the 1st lumbrical muscle.
  • The lumbricals are essential for the fingers' precision grip and fine motor control.
  • These muscles flex the MCP joints and extend the PIP and DIP joints, coordinating with other hand muscles.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extension. The extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis proprius, extensor digitorum communis, and extensor digiti minimi extend the MCP joints.

 

Option C. Adduction. Adduction of the thumb is produced by the adductor pollicis, while the adduction of the other four digits is produced by palmar interossei muscles.

 

Option D. Abduction. Abduction of the thumb is produced by the abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis; abduction of the fifth digit is produced by the abductor digiti minimi; abduction of fingers 2-5 is produced by the dorsal interossei muscles.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The marked joint in the hand is the MCP joint of the index finger.
  • The lumbricals function to perform the flexion at the MCP joint and extension of the PIP and DIP joints.

choices.text: Winging of scapula

questions.text: Damage to median nerve produces:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ape thumb

 

Option C.

 

MEDIAN NERVE DEFORMITY

 

  • In Ape thumb deformity due to median nerve palsy, the thumb is adducted and laterally rotated and lies in same plane as rest of finger, due to unopposed action of extensor pollicis longus (radial nerve) and adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).
  • There is a limited range of motion of the thumb.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Claw hand. Claw Hand is a hand deformity with hyperextension of the metacarpophalengeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalengeal (IP) joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. The most common cause is the ulnar nerve injury. Complete claw hand involves all the digits and results from both Ulnar and Median Nerve Palsy. Incomplete or Partial claw hand involves only ulnar 2 digits and is due to isolated Ulnar Nerve Palsy.

 

 

Partial claw hand

 

Option B. Winging of scapula. In a patient with a winged scapula, the medial or lateral aspect of the scapula appears to be protruding from the back. The most common etiology of a winged scapula is usually due to damage or impaired innervation to the serratus anterior muscle. The nerve that innervates this muscle is the long thoracic nerve. Some patients may also complain of an inability to raise the affected arm above their head. This dysfunction results in the medial border of the scapula giving a winged-like appearance. 

 

 

Option D. Wrist drop. Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits, those whose radial nerve function has been compromised cannot actively extend them. As such, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Damage to the median nerve produces ape thumb deformity of the hand where the thumb is unable to abduct and oppose and remains in the same plane as the fingers.

questions.text: Labourer’s Nerve is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Median nerve

 

Option B.

 

MEDIAN NERVE

 

  • Median nerve is also known as labourer’s nerve.
  • It is called so because it innervations all those muscles responsible for complex movements in daily life.
  • It supplies large flexor muscles of forearm and five intrinsic muscles of hand which help in movement of the thumb. 
  • Since, the nerve controls the coarse movements of the hand, therefore, it is called "labourer's nerve".

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. It is also known as musician’s nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The median nerve is also known as labourer’s nerve because it performs the coarse movements of the hand that are required by the labourers.

choices.text: Flex the distal phalanx of the thumb

questions.text: Compression of a nerve within the carpal tunnel produces inability to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oppose the thumb

 

Option D.

 

NERVE COMPRESSION IN CARPAL TUNNEL

 

  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome involves compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel.
  • The median nerve supplies:
    • Thenar muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis (superficial head), and Opponens pollicis
    • Lateral 2 lumbricals
    • Sensation to the lateral 3 fingers
  • Opposition of the thumb is a complex movement involving abduction, flexion, and medial rotation of the thumb.
  • It is primarily performed by the Opponens pollicis (innervated by median nerve).
  • Thus, in carpal tunnel syndrome, opposition is impaired.
  • Abduction of thumb can be also carried out by abductor pollicis longus supplied by radial nerve.
  • Flexor pollicis longus will be intact to carry out flexion at thumb phalanx as it is supplied by Anterior Interosseous nerve, branch of median nerve above carpal tunnel, and adductor pollicis will cause adduction as it is supplied by ulnar nerve.


     

    • Ape thumb deformity: In median nerve palsy, the thumb is adducted and laterally rotated and lies in same plane as rest of finger, due to unopposed action of extensor pollicis longus (radial nerve) and adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).


       

    • Loss of opposition

    • Sensory loss in lateral 3 of digits and 2/3rd palm (autonomous zone is tip of index and middle finger).

    • Anterior dislocation of lunate may cause median nerve compression, making its reduction an emergency

    • Kiloh-Nevin sign (lateral 1/2 of Flexor Digitorum Profundus and Flexor Pollicis Longus) supplied by anterior interosseous nerve the pinch of thumb and index finger is strong if AIN is intact and this is called as Kiloh-Nevin sign.

 

Note: AIN supplies: Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) + Pronator quadratus (PQ) + Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) (Lateral 1/2).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abduct the thumb. Due to low median nerve palsy i.e., compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel, there is weakness of the thumb abduction and opposition. Abduction of the thumb is controlled by the abductor pollicis brevis and longus muscles which are innervated by both median and radial nerves respectively. If the median nerve is compressed, then the thumb abduction movement can also be performed by the abductor pollicis longus muscle which is supplied by the radial nerve. Thus, due to median nerve compression, thumb abduction may become weak but will not be lost completely.

 

Option B. Adduct the thumb. This movement is primarily controlled by the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Carpal tunnel syndrome typically does not affect the adduction of the thumb directly. 

 

Option C. Flex the distal phalanx of the thumb. The flexion of the distal phalanx of the thumb is controlled by the flexor pollicis longus muscle which is supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve branch of the median nerve above the carpal tunnel. Thus, this movement is not affected by the median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Due to median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel, the main movement lost is the opposition of the thumb, which characteristically present as the ape thumb deformity of the hand.

questions.text:
Median nerve is injured during: 

 

  1. Elbow dislocation

  2. Fracture lateral epicondyle of humerus

  3. Fracture medial epicondyle of humerus

  4. Supracondylar fracture of humerus
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 1 & 4

 

Option C.

 

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • The median nerve can be affected by acute traumatic, chronic micro traumatic, and compressive lesions.

  • The nerve can also become damaged during multiple-cause degenerative processes and neuropathies.

  • Median nerve is injured in elbow dislocation, wrist dislocation, supracondylar fracture humerus and carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

1. Elbow dislocation: During posterior elbow dislocation, median nerve (along with the brachial artery) can get injured due to stretching or entrapment. Though less common than ulnar nerve injury, median nerve involvement is definitely possible.

 

4. Supracondylar fracture of humerus: This is the most common fracture associated with median nerve injury in children. Especially in extension-type supracondylar fractures, the anteriorly located median nerve is highly vulnerable. It may also lead to Volkmann ischemic contracture due to associated vascular compromise.

 

Explanation:

 

2. Fracture lateral epicondyle of humerus: False. The radial nerve (or its deep branch, the posterior interosseous nerve) is more closely related to the lateral epicondyle, not the median nerve. Median nerve runs medially, and is not typically affected by lateral epicondyle injuries.

 

3. Fracture medial epicondyle of humerus: False. Ulnar nerve passes behind the medial epicondyle, and is the nerve at risk in such fractures. The median nerve is not near the medial epicondyle, so it is not typically injured here.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The common etiology of the median nerve injury are the elbow dislocation and supracondylar fracture of humerus.

choices.text: Posterior Interosseous Nerve palsy

questions.text: A patient complaint of flexion of interphalangeal joints and hyperextension of MCP of hands. He is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Claw hand

 

Option C.

 

CLAW HAND

 

  • The question classically describes a Claw Hand.
  • It occurs due to involvement of C8-T1 nerve roots which control the Lumbricals and Interossei.
  • The function of Lumbricals and Interossei is flexion at the MCP joints and extension at the IP joints.
  • When these nerve roots are affected as in Ulnar Nerve Palsy, Klumpke’s palsy or Thoracic Outlet Syndrome, the function of these muscles gets impaired, resulting in flexion at IP joints and hyperextension at MCP joints, called CLAW HAND.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior Interosseous Nerve palsy. PIN palsy involved weakness of metacarpal extension, wrist extension in neutral or ulnar deviation. The wrist will extend with radial deviation due to intact ECRL (radial nerve) and absent ECU (PIN).

 

Option B. Dupuytren’s contracture. Dupuytren disease starts as a palpable nodule in the palm, usually at the distal palmar crease. The nodules enlarge into cords and present with palpable cords along the palm. As the cords thicken and shorten, they cause fixed flexion contractures of the fingers at the MCP and PIP joints. At this stage, there is loss of range of motion of the hand and palpable cords in the palm extending into the affected digits. The 4th digit is most often affected, followed by the 5th digit. In most cases, palpation of the nodules does not elicit pain unless the ulnar nerve is compressed.

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy. The neonate presents with the arm hanging limply from the shoulder with adduction at the shoulder, internal rotation of the upper arm, pronation of the forearm, and an outward direction of the palm, giving the appearance of a "waiter's tip posture." The arm cannot be raised from the side, and all power of flexion of the elbow is lost due to the paralysis of the biceps muscle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presenting complaint of IP joint flexion and MCP joint hyperextension is suggestive of presence of claw hand caused by ulnar nerve injury.

choices.text: Median nerve injury
Radial nerve injury
Ulnar nerve injury

questions.text: Knuckle-Bender splint is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve injury

 

Option C.

 

KNUCKLE BENDER SPLINT

 

  • A Knuckle Bender Splint is an extension assist splint to bring mobility to the interphalangeal joints.
  • It is used for ulnar nerve palsy or to assist weak intrinsic muscles.
  • Provides dynamic MP flexion. 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve injury. In median nerve injury, wrist splint is more commonly used. Knuckle bender can also be used, but not commonly than a wrist splint.

 

Option B. Radial nerve injury. For radial nerve injury, a cock-up splint is used.

 

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy. In brachial plexus injury, aeroplane splint is used.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The knuckle bender splint is used commonly for ulnar nerve injury more than median nerve injury.

questions.text: Lumbricals palsy causes:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Claw hand

 

Option A.

 

LUMBRICALS PALSY

 

  • Paralysis of the lumbricals is caused by the injury to the ulnar nerve.
  • This presents as a claw hand (also known as intrinsic minus hand).
  • It is characterized by MCP joint hyperextension with PIP and DIP joint flexion caused by an imbalance between strong extrinsics and deficient intrinsics.
  • Strong extrinsics (EDC) leads to unopposed extension of the MCP joint.
  • Strong FDP and FDS leads to unopposed flexion of the PIP and DIP.
  • Since there is an involvement of the lumbricals, the claw hand deformity will be worse in the 4-5th digits.
  • It will not be severe in the 2nd and 3rd digits because the lumbricals of these fingers are innervated by the median nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erb’s palsy. In erb’s palsy, there is paralysis of brachialis, biceps brachii, deltoid, rotator cuff, and supinator muscles. This leads to a characteristic policeman’s tip deformity of the limb where the shoulder is adducted and medially rotated and the forearm is extended and pronated.

 

 

Option C. Mallet finger. Mallet Finger is a finger deformity caused by disruption of the terminal extensor tendon distal to DIP joint. This leads to loss of active DIP extension.

 

 

Option D. Hammer toe. Hammer Toe is a lesser toe deformity characterized by PIP flexion, DIP extension and MTP slight extension. It is caused due to plantar plate injury/over pull of EDL/intrinsic imbalance/rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lumbricals palsy is caused by the ulnar nerve palsy, which leads to claw hand, more pronounced in the 4th and 5th digits.

choices.text: Ulnar nerve alone
Median nerve alone
Median and ulnar nerves
Radial and ulnar nerves

questions.text: Following an incised wound in the front of wrist, the subject is unable to oppose the tips of the little finger and the thumb. The nerve(s) involved is/are
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Median and ulnar nerves

 

Option C)

 

NERVE INJURY FOLLOWING INCISED WOUND

 

  • The patient has inability to oppose little finger (paralysis of opponens digiti minimi) and oppose thumb (paralysis of opponens pollicis).
  • So, both ulnar and median nerves are paralyzed.
  • The opponens digiti minimi is paralysed due to injury to the ulnar nerve while the opponens pollicis is paralysed due to injury to the median nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve alone. The ulnar nerve innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, including those responsible for fine motor movements and grip strength in the ulnar aspect of the hand. While the ulnar nerve does not directly control opposition of the thumb, it does play a role in stabilizing the hand during this movement. Additionally, it controls movements of the little finger. So, while it is involved in the scenario described, it alone does not fully account for the inability to oppose the thumb and little finger simultaneously.

 

Option B. Median nerve alone. The median nerve innervates several muscles in the forearm and hand, including the muscles of the thumb. It is primarily responsible for opposition of the thumb. However, the median nerve alone does not directly control opposition of the little finger. Thus, median nerve alone cannot account for the inability of the opposition of both the thumb and the little finger simultaneously.

 

Option D. Radial and ulnar nerves. The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles in the forearm and hand, controlling movements such as wrist extension and finger extension. While the ulnar nerve controls movements of the little finger, the radial nerve does not directly contribute to the opposition of either the thumb or little finger.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The median nerve is responsible for the inability to oppose the thumb, while the ulnar nerve is likely contributing to the inability to oppose the little finger.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, there is injury to both the median and ulnar nerves leading to inability of the opposition of little finger and thumb.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with a humerus fracture as shown in the figure below. Which is the nerve likely to be involved by the fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

Option B)

 

  • The X-ray image shows fracture of spiral groove of humerus which is related to the Radial Nerve. It is classically known as Holstein-Lewis Fracture.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. It is injured in the fracture of the medial condyle of the humerus.

 

Option C. Median nerve. The median nerve can be injured in the supracondylar humerus fracture.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. This nerve is injured more commonly in shoulder dislocation, after axillary nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows the humerus shaft fracture.
  • It is associated with radial nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient cant extend his wrist after he has met with an accident. He has no sensory loss. Level at which the affected nerve is injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spiral groove of humerus

 

Option A)

 

WRIST DROP

 

  • The inability to extend the wrist i.e., wrist drop, is a classic sign of radial nerve injury.
  • The radial nerve travels down the arm and wraps around the humerus in the spiral groove. 
  • It then travels through the forearm. 
  • It innervates the muscles responsible for wrist and finger extension.
  • An injury to the radial nerve in the spiral groove of the humerus typically results in wrist drop because it affects the nerve's innervation to the wrist extensor muscles. 
  • Importantly, sensation is often preserved because the sensory branch of the radial nerve usually branches off lower in the arm. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Head of radius. The radial nerve passes near the head of the radius. An injury here is more likely to cause pain and affect forearm supination rather than a complete wrist drop without sensory loss.

 

Option C. Near medial epicondyle. The ulnar nerve passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Injury around this area may lead to ulnar claw hand deformity. 

 

Option D. Surgical neck of humerus. At this level, axillary nerve is affected. Axillary nerve paralysis may cause weakness of shoulder abduction and loss of sensation in the lower half of the deltoid area. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given case, the level affected is the spiral groove of the humerus, from where the radial nerve passes. 
  • Thus, there will be symptoms of wrist drop in the patient without any sensory loss.

choices.text: Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist
Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist
Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury
Weak extensor of the wrist

questions.text: Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus is
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist

 

Option B)

 

MUSCLES OF WRIST MOVEMENT

 

  • Wrist flexion:
    • Flexor carpi ulnaris – prime mover
    • Flexor carpi radialis – prime mover
    • Palmaris longus – tightens the skin and fascia in palm
    • Flexor digitorum superficialis – assisrt only, finger flexor
  • Wrist extension:
    • Extensor carpi radialis longus – prime mover
    • Extensor carpi radialis brevis – prime mover
    • Extensor carpi ulnaris
    • Extensor digitorum – assist only
  • Wrist radial deviation:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
    • Extensor carpi radialis
  • Wrist ulnar deviation:
    • Flexor carpi ulnaris
    • Extensor carpi ulnaris
  • Thus, the extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.
  • Radial deviation because it is attached to base of second metacarpal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist. The extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor of the wrist, but it is not the ulnar deviator. The ulnar deviation is performed by the extensor carpi ulnaris muscle, while the extensor carpi radialis longus muscle performs the radial deviation of the wrist.

 

Option C. Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury. Due to PIN injury, the ulnar wrist extensors and the MCP joint extensors are compromised. The most commonly affected muscle is extensor carpi ulnaris.

 

Option D. Weak extensor of wrist. The extensor carpi ulnaris is generally considered as the weak extensor of the wrist.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.

choices.text: Common peroneal nerve palsy

questions.text: High stepping gait is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Common peroneal nerve palsy

 

Option B)

 

HIGH STEPPING GAIT

 

  • Steppage gait is the inability to lift the foot while walking due to the weakness of dorsiflexors of the ankle joint.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates the dorsiflexors, i.e., tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, and extensor hallucis longus muscles. These are responsible for ankle dorsiflexion.
  • Because of its superficial location, the peroneal nerve is vulnerable to compression during surgical procedures, tight cast placements, and other traumatic conditions sustained during sports.
  • The muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of leg are paralyzed namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, extensor hallucis longus and peroneus tertius (supplied by deep peroneal nerve) and peroneus longus and brevis (supplied by superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Patients with diabetes seem to be affected more often.
  • Any compression of the common peroneal nerve leads to foot drop.
  • The person will be unable to dorsiflex during the heel strike, and the foot remains flat on the ground.
  • Sometimes this can also cause toe drag and inability to clear the foot, potentially leading to falls.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CTEV. CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus), commonly known as clubfoot, is a congenital condition where the foot is twisted inward and downward. This condition typically presents with a rigid foot deformity, making it difficult for the individual to walk normally. However, it typically manifest as a "in-toeing gait."

 

Option C. Polio. Polio is a viral infectious disease that affects the nervous system, particularly motor neurons. It can lead to muscle weakness and paralysis, often asymmetrically. However, polio-induced gait abnormalities usually involve weakness or paralysis of specific muscle groups. It manifests as a "hand-to-knee gait." The gait is a sum of quadriceps weakness and fixed knee flexion deformity.

 

Option D. Cerebral palsy. There are 4 gait patterns seen in spastic hemiplegic CP. The type 1 presents with a foot drop due to weak dorsiflexors. Type 2 presents with true foot equinus due to spasticity/contracture of gastrosoleus. Type 3 presents with stiff knee gait due to hamstring/quadriceps co-contraction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • High stepping gait is seen in common peroneal nerve injury.
  • This occurs as a result of foot drop from weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

choices.text: Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion
Loss of ankle reflex
Sensory impairment on lateral aspect of leg extending to the dorsum of foot

questions.text: Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the lateral aspect of head of fibula results in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of ankle reflex

 

Option C)

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • In patients with a peroneal nerve injury, the most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop or catching the toes while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology.
  • It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe web space.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • Ankle reflex is mediated by tibial nerve.
  • Muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of leg are paralyzed namely – tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, extensor hallucis longus and peroneus tertius (supplied by deep peroneal nerve) and peroneus longus and brevis (supplied by superficial peroneal nerve) – presenting as foot drop.

 

 

  • Lateral border of foot and lateral side of little toe are unaffected (sural nerve mainly formed from tibial nerve).
  • The medial border of foot as far as the ball of big toe is completely unaffected (saphenous nerve, a branch of femoral nerve).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • An injury to the common peroneal nerve at the lateral aspect of the head of fibula results in weakening of the ankle dorsiflexion, leading to classical foot drop deformity.
  • There is also a sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the leg, extending to the dorsum of the foot.
  • The ankle reflex is mediated by the tibial nerve; thus it is not affected in the common peroneal nerve injury.

choices.text: Chronic ischemia to limbs due to popliteal artery injury
Partial injury to sciatic nerve
Complete injury of sciatic nerve
Injury to hamstring muscles

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady sustained a lacerated wound on the back of right thigh by a horn of a bull. The wound was sutured. Two months later she developed foot drop and an ulcer on the dorsum of the foot. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Partial injury to sciatic nerve

 

Option B)

 

SCIATIC NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal component seems to be affected as ulcer is only on dorsum of foot supplied by common peroneal nerve.
  • Sciatic nerve has two components, tibial nerve (centrally arranged fibers) and common peroneal nerve (peripherally arranged fibers).
  • The sciatic nerve divides into its terminal branches, the tibial and common peroneal nerves, usually just below the mid-thigh.
  • The injury to sciatic nerve sometimes can present as an injury only to common peroneal nerve because these fibers are peripheral and more prone to pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic ischemia to limbs due to popliteal artery injury. Popliteal artery entrapment syndrome (PAES) is a very rare pathology that can cause lower extremity ischemia in healthy young people. Chronic critical limb ischemia is manifested by pain at rest, non-healing wounds and gangrene. Ischemic rest pain is typically described as a burning pain in the arch or distal foot that occurs while the patient is recumbent but is relieved when the patient returns to a position in which the feet are dependent. Gangrene is usually found on the toes. 

 

Option C. Complete injury of sciatic nerve. Sciatic nerve injury occurs due to trauma (pressure, stretching or cutting) to the nerve and can cause symptoms such as paresthesias, loss of muscle power and pain. Trauma like hip dislocation and acetabular fracture; Iatrogenic causes like Direct surgical trauma, Faulty positioning during anaesthesia, Injection of neurotoxic substances, Tourniquets, Dressings, casts or faulty fitting orthotics, and Radiation. The common symptoms are pain and abnormal gait pattern, External rotation and abduction contracture of the hip, Equinovarus or Equinus deformity, Muscular weakness/atrophy, and Motor and sensory deficit such as paraesthesia and numbness.

 

Option D. Injury to hamstring muscles. Hamstring injuries most commonly occur at the myotendinous junction in running athletes as a result of sudden hip flexion and knee extension. The patient may feel a sudden pain in the posterior thigh during running, kicking or jumping activity. Occasionally, a "pop" felt. Common symptoms includes posterior thigh pain, hamstring tightness and pain with sitting. There may be a palpable mass in middle 1/3 of posterior thigh. The patient walks with a "stiff-legged" gait (avoiding knee and hip flexion). The patient may also have peroneal nerve weakness.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given case scenario describes the presentation of foot drop and ulcers on the dorsum of the foot.
  • These are suggestive of partial injury to the sciatic nerve with some injury to the common peroneal nerve because the presentation is that of foot drop and ulcer on foot dorsum.
  • The common peroneal nerve injury leads to foot drop due to motor loss to foot dorsiflexors, sensory loss at the lateral side of the leg and dorsum of the foot.
  • Thus, in the given case, the patient had partial injury to the sciatic nerve (or injury to the common peroneal nerve).

choices.text: Occupational – excessive use of vibration instruments

questions.text: Most common cause of carpal tunnel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Idiopathic

 

Option B)

 

ETIOLOGY OF CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders: Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, sarcoidosis.
  • Injury related: Synovitis of tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle’s fracture)

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually idiopathic.
  • The other causes include pregnancy, chronic alcoholism, and use of vibratory tools in occupation.

questions.text: Meralgia Paresthetica is due to involvement of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

Option A)

 

MERALGIA PARESTHETICA

 

  • The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is a pure sensory nerve vulnerable to compression as it passes from the lumbosacral plexus towards the inguinal ligament and into the subcutaneous tissue of the anterior thigh.
  • Meralgia paresthetica is a clinical condition that involves pain and dysesthesia in the anterolateral thigh associated with compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. 
  • The condition is caused by injury or entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) and can be spontaneous or iatrogenic.
  • Spontaneous causes include diabetes mellitus, lead poisoning, alcohol use disorder, and hypothyroidism resulting in an isolated neuropathy of the LFCN.
  • Mechanical causes due to external direct pressure from tight seat belts, belts, or restrictive clothing.
  • Additional mechanical causes include increased intra-abdominal pressure from obesity, pregnancy, or tumors.
  • Iatrogenic causes due to surgical intervention include hip replacement surgery, spine surgery, laparoscopic inguinal repair, pelvic osteotomy, surgery in the area of the anterior superior iliac spine, iliac crest bone graft harvesting, acetabular fracture surgery, laparoscopic myomectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, vein harvesting for coronary bypass surgeries, or bariatric surgery.
  • Patients commonly present with burning pain, paresthesias over the upper lateral thigh.
  • Symptoms are typically unilateral.
  • Onset is usually subacute over days to weeks.
  • Patients will typically point to or rub their outer thigh when describing symptoms and may have associated hair loss over the area secondary to repeated rubbing.
  • Symptoms may be associated with prolonged hip extension, such as walking or rising from a seated position or prolonged standing.
  • Symptoms may also be relieved by hip flexion movements such as sitting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ilioinguinal nerve. Ilioinguinal neuralgia is a frequent cause of pain in the lower abdomen and the upper thigh and is commonly caused by entrapment or injury of the nerve after lower abdominal surgeries. The ilioinguinal nerve is responsible for motor innervation of the transverse abdominis and internal oblique muscles. It provides sensory innervation to a region of the upper anteromedial thigh. In males, it also supplies sensory innervation to the anterior surface of the scrotum and root of the penis and in females, supplies sensory innervation to the labia majora and mons pubis. Male or female patients with ilioinguinal neuralgia may complain of pain, paresthesia and abnormal sensation in the area supplied by the nerve.

 

Option C. Genitofemoral nerve. Genitofemoral neuralgia is a cause of neuropathic pain that is characterized by chronic neuropathic groin pain that is localized along the distribution of the genitofemoral nerve. The symptoms include groin pain, paresthesias, and burning sensation spreading from the lower abdomen to the medial aspect of the thigh. It may present with scrotal pain in male, while females experience symptoms radiating to the labia majora and mons pubis. Genitofemoral neuropathy has been attributed to iatrogenic nerve injury during inguinal and femoral herniorrhaphy.

 

Option D. Saphenous nerve. Compression of the saphenous nerve typically occurs at the adductor canal or at the infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve as it courses near the medial femoral condyle. Patients typically complain of vague dull or achy pain located in the area of the anteromedial knee, with burning or other neuropathic qualities. The pain is often reported as worse with stairs, prolonged walking, and sitting.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica is caused by the compression of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.
  • It is characterized by paresthesia in the upper lateral side of the thigh.
  • The other entrapment syndromes caused by compression of nerves are described below:

choices.text: Flexor carpi ulnaris
Extensor pollicis longus

questions.text: In a patient with history of trauma of forearm and X-ray showing fracture of proximal part of medial bone with dislocation of proximal part of lateral bone, the muscles which may be paralyzed are
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C)

 

MONTEGGIA FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • The X-ray description and the image are pointing towards Monteggia fracture.
  • Monteggia fracture is characterized by fracture of proximal part of Ulna (Medial bone) and dislocation of radial head (Lateral bone).
  • It affects the posterior interosseous nerve.
  • It commonly occurs in children, in a fall onto an outstretched hand or a direct blow.
  • Out of the four options, Extensors are supplied by Posterior Interosseous Nerve, which is a branch of Radial Nerve.
  • The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension due to weakness of the extensor pollicis longus muscle.
  • When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor carpi ulnaris. This muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. It flexes and adducts the wrist. This muscle’s tendon is susceptible to involvement in the Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

Option B. Adductor pollicis. This muscle is also innervated by the ulnar nerve (deep branch). It functions in the adduction of the thumb, helpful in pinching and gripping movements. A ganglion, fracture of the hook of the hamate, or hypertrophic scars caused by repeated microtrauma are the most common causes of compression of the deep motor branch of the ulnar nerve, leading to adductor pollicis paralysis.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis. It is innervated by the median nerve. It performs the opposition movement of the thumb i.e., it allows the tip of the thumb to touch the tip of the fingers.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray description of the patient in the question is of Monteggia fracture-dislocation.
  • Due to monteggia fracture, the nerve most commonly affected is the posterior interosseous nerve.
  • This nerve supplied the extensor pollicis longus muscle which controls the extension of the little finger.
  • So, in this case, the muscle paralysed is the extensor pollicis longus.

choices.text: Flexor digitorum profundus
Flexor carpi radialis

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of difficulty in adducting his fingers and flexion of extended metacarpophalangeal joint. Muscles that are paralyzed are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interossei

 

Option A.

 

MOTOR SUPPLY OF ULNAR NERVE

 

  • Forearm:
    • Flexor carpi ulnaris: weakness of ulnar deviation and flexion of wrist
    • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus: weakness of flexion of the terminal phalanx of the fourth and fifth digits, and wrist flexion, particularly medially
  • Hand:
    • Hypothenar muscles: atrophy of hypothenar eminence
      • Palmaris brevis
      • Abductor digiti minimi
      • Flexor digiti minimi
      • Opponens digiti minimi
    • Thenar muscles:
      • Adductor pollicis
      • Deep head of flexor pollicis brevis
    • Four palmar Interossei: weakness in adduction of fingers
    • Four dorsal interossei: weakness in abduction of 2-4th digits
    • Medial two lumbricals: weakness in MCP flexion and PIP and DIP extension

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lumbricals. The paralysis of the lumbricals of the hand causes the weakness of the MCP joint flexion and PIP and DIP joint extension.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum profundus. Paralysis of this muscle weakens the flexion of the terminal phalanx and the wrist.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis. Its paralysis can cause the weakness of wrist flexion and abduction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Difficulty in adducting the fingers is noticed when the interossei are paralysed.
  • This can be tested by positive card test (patient unable to hold the card firmly between the fingers).

 

 

  • Since there is weakness in adduction, the fingers will appear abducted.
  • The abducted position of the little finger appears as Wartenberg’s sign.

questions.text: In fracture of distal half of humerus, the nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radial nerve

 

Option C)

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Radial nerve is involved in fracture of distal part of humerus it is called as Holstein-Lewis sign.
  • Radial nerve injuries usually occur in fractures affecting a 10–15cm path where the radial nerve courses along the periosteum of the middle and middle-distal humerus.
  • As the nerve has very little mobility in this area, and minimal protection, it is highly susceptible to injury.
  • Transverse and spiral fractures are most likely to result in radial nerve palsy.
  • These are followed by displaced high-energy fracture patterns.
  • In cases of displacement, stretching of the nerve is a common source of injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Axillary nerve. Axillary nerve is injured in the fracture of the surgical neck of humerus, anterior and inferior shoulder dislocations, and from intramuscular injections in the deltoid region.

 

Option B. Median nerve. Median nerve is injured in elbow dislocation, wrist dislocation, supracondylar humerus fracture, and in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. The fracture of medial epicondyle of the humerus is the most common cause of ulnar nerve injury as the nerve passes just behind the medial epicondyle.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In the fracture of the distal half of the humerus, involving the spiral groove, the most commonly injured nerve is the radial nerve as the nerve crosses the bone at the distal half of the shaft.

choices.text: Anterior Interosseous Nerve
Posterior Interosseous Nerve

questions.text: Dorsum of 1st web space of hand is an autonomous zone for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

Option A)

 

AUTONOMOUS ZONES IN HAND FOR PERIPHERAL NERVES

 

  • These are the regions where single nerve roots supply distinct and non-overlapping areas of skin.
  • The “autonomous zones” represent only a small portion of any dermatome and only a few nerve roots have such autonomous zones.
  • Radial nerve: 1st dorsal web space of hand (Anatomical snuff box)
  • Median nerve: Distal phalanx (tip) of index finger (2nd finger), Tip of thumb
  • Ulnar nerve: Distal phalanx (tip) of little finger (5th finger)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve. This nerve provides sensory supply to the carpal bones of the wrist.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. This nerve provides sensory fibers to the dorsal aspect of the wrist capsule. It does not provide cutaneous branches.

 

Option D. Median nerve. The autonomous zone for the median nerve are the tip of the index finger and tip of the thumb.

 

Educational objective:

 

The radial nerve’s autonomous zone in the hand is the 1st dorsal web space of the hand i.e., the anatomical snuff box.

choices.text: 1st carpometacarpal joint arthritis

questions.text: Tinel’s sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carpal tunnel syndrome

 

Option D)

 

TINEL’S SIGN

 

  • Sensory symptoms in carpal tunnel syndrome can be reproduced by tapping/percussion along the course of median nerve in the wrist. 
  • This causes tingling sensation.
  • This is called as Tinel’s sign and it is positive in Carpal Tunnel syndrome.
  • It is provocative test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Avascular necrosis of scaphoid. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid is a condition where the blood supply to the scaphoid bone in the wrist is compromised, leading to bone tissue death. While avascular necrosis of the scaphoid can cause wrist pain and dysfunction, Tinel's sign is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option B. Kienbock’s disease. Kienbock's disease is a condition where the blood supply to the lunate bone in the wrist is disrupted, leading to lunate bone necrosis. Similar to avascular necrosis of the scaphoid, Tinel's sign is not typically associated with Kienbock's disease.

 

Option C. 1st carpometacarpal joint arthritis. Arthritis affecting the first carpometacarpal joint can cause pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion in the thumb. While arthritis can lead to joint compression and nerve irritation, Tinel's sign is not commonly elicited in cases of first carpometacarpal joint arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tinel’s sign is a provocative test to evaluate the sensations in a nerve.
  • Out of the given choices, the only nerve-related condition is the carpal tunnel syndrome, rest are the vascular and arthritic conditions.
  • Thus, Tinel’s sign is positive in carpal tunnel syndrome, as in, when the median nerve is tapped or percussed along its course, it produces tingling sensation in the wrist and hand.

choices.text: Anterior Interosseous Nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve supply of the marked muscle.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Median Nerve

 

Option B.

 

  • The marked muscle is 1st lumbrical.
  • 1st and 2nd lumbricals are supplied by median nerve.
  • 3rd and 4th lumbricals are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The median nerve gives motor innervation to the superficial volar forearm group (pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus), intermediate group (FDS), deep group (lateral FDP, FPL, pronator quadratus), and hand (1-2 lumbricals, opponens pollicis, APB, flexor pollicis brevis).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Radial nerve. It innervates the triceps, anconeus, extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL), extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB), brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve. It gives motor innervation to the anterior compartment of the forearm, and hand. In the forearm, it supplies the FCU and medial FDP. In the hand, it supplies the hypothenar muscles, medial 2 lumbricals, adductor pollicis, palmar and dorsal interossei of hand.

 

Option D. Anterior interosseous nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the deep compartment of the anterior forearm i.e., Flexor pollicis longus, Lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (index and middle fingers), and Pronator quadratus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The marked muscle in the image is the 1st lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

choices.text: Deep branch of ulnar nerve
Superficial branch of ulnar nerve
Anterior Interosseous branch of median nerve

questions.text: Adductor pollicis is supplied by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deep branch of ulnar nerve

 

Option A.

 

ADDUCTOR POLLICIS

 

  • The adductor pollicis is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve (C8-T1).
  • The deep branch travels between the muscles of the hypothenar eminence to the deep compartment of the palm.
  • In addition to the adductor pollicis, the deep branch also innervates the hypothenar muscles, the medial two lumbricals, the interossei of the hand, and the palmaris brevis.
  • In case of ulnar nerve palsy involving the deep branch, adductor pollicis is paralyzed.
  • To test this, the patient is asked to hold a book between thumb and palm by using flexor pollicis longus (supplied by AIN nerve).
  • This produces flexion at interphalangeal joint, while holding book.
  • This is known as Froment’s Sign.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Median nerve. The median nerve gives motor innervation to the superficial volar forearm group (pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus), intermediate group (FDS), deep group (lateral FDP, FPL, pronator quadratus), and hand (1-2 lumbricals, opponens pollicis, APB, flexor pollicis brevis).

 

Option C. Superficial branch of ulnar nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve provides branches that innervate the hypothenar muscles (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, and opponens digiti muscles), palmaris brevis muscle, and skin of palmar aspect of medial one and a half digits.

 

Option D. Anterior interosseous branch of median nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the deep compartment of the anterior forearm i.e., Flexor pollicis longus, Lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (index and middle fingers), and Pronator quadratus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The adductor pollicis muscle of the hand is supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

choices.text: High ulnar nerve palsy
Low ulnar nerve palsy
Combined median and ulnar nerve palsy
Guyon’s Canal entrapment of ulnar nerve

questions.text: Ulnar paradox is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High ulnar nerve palsy

 

Option A.

 

ULNAR PARADOX

 

  • In high ulnar nerve palsy (close to elbow), FDP muscle is denervated.
  • As a result, there is weakening of the flexion of the IP joints.
  • Since, forearm muscles are involved, the clawing of the fingers is less as compared to low ulnar nerve palsy.
  • This phenomenon is called ulnar paradox.
  • This is due to sparing of FDP in low lesions, which causes more flexion of interphalangeal joints.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Low ulnar nerve palsy.  Clawing is present with low ulnar nerve injury. There is clawing of ulnar 2 digits, finger cannot be completely extended. There is hyperextension of MCP joint, because of unopposed action of long extensors. There is no extension of IP joints, they remain flexed due to unopposed action of long flexors. Thus clawing occurs, with hyperextension of MCP joints & flexion of IP joints.

 

Option C. Combined median and ulnar nerve palsy. When Low Median and Low Ulnar Nerve Lesions occur, there is loss of sensation in palm, loss of Intrinsic muscle function, loss of thumb opposition and adduction. When there is High Median and High Ulnar Nerve Lesions, there is hand anesthesia, and loss of flexors and intrinsics.

 

Option D. Guyon’s canal entrapment of ulnar nerve. There is weakness/paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand innervated by the ulnar nerve, which may present as a weakening of the handgrip and clawing of the fourth and fifth digits. Hypothenar atrophy may be present in more advanced cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ulnar paradox phenomenon is seen due to high ulnar nerve palsy i.e., when the ulnar nerve is injured at the level of elbow.
  • This appears as clawing of the fingers, but the clawing is less severe than that of the low ulnar nerve palsy.

choices.text: Ulnar nerve palsy
Median nerve palsy
Musculocutaneous nerve palsy
Posterior Interosseous nerve palsy

questions.text: Froment’s Sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve palsy

 

Option A.

 

FROMENT’S SIGN

 

  • In case of ulnar nerve palsy, adductor pollicis supplied by ulnar nerve is paralyzed.
  • So, patient holds the book between thumb and palm by using flexor pollicis longus (supplied by AIN nerve).
  • A normal individual will be able to maintain a hold on the object without difficulty. 
  • With ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will experience difficulty maintaining a hold and this produces flexion at interphalangeal joint of the thumb, while holding book to maintain grip pressure causing a pinching effect.
  • This is known as a positive froment’s sign.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Median nerve palsy. Benediction Hand Sign can be seen due to median nerve palsy when the patient is asked to oppose the tip of the thumb and the tip of the little finger. In the next step, the patient is asked to make a fist. Paralysis of the opponens pollicis makes it impossible to bring the tips of the thumb and little finger into opposition. Because of this opposition weakness, the patient cannot make a fist. This produces the deformity where only the ring and little fingers are flexed while the other digits remain extended. Paralysis of the opponens, abductor pollicis brevis, and flexor pollicis brevis muscles coupled with the antagonistic pull of the adductor pollicis causes the thumb to lie in the plane of the fingers, creating a deformity resembling an apes hand, and the patient is unable to oppose the thumb. This is called ape thumb deformity.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Froment’s sign is seen in ulnar nerve palsy due to the paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.

questions.text: Card test is done for testing the function of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmar interossei

 

Option B.

 

CARD TEST

 

  • The card test is done for testing the weakness of the palmar interossei muscle.
  • The patient is asked to hold a card between their fingers.
  • The inability to do so indicates the weakness of palmar interossei due to ulnar nerve injury, leading to inability to adduct the fingers.

 

 

  • Nerve supply of interossei: Deep branch of Ulnar Nerve
  • Functions of Interossei:
    • These muscles synchronously assist in flexion of the MCP joints and extension of IP joints.
    • PAd – Palmar Interossei – Adduction of fingers
    • DAb – Dorsal Interossei – Abduction of fingers

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lumbricals. Ask the patient to fully flex the fingers and at end range, ask the patient to tuck the fingertips tighter into flexion. There is characterized paradoxical extension of the IP joints while attempting to flex the fingers. This is known as Lumbrical Plus Finger.

 

 

Option C. Dorsal interossei. Positive Egawa’s test is due to weakness of dorsal interossei, where side-to-side movements of middle finger becomes weak.

 

Option D. Adductor pollicis. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, adductor pollicis supplied by ulnar nerve is paralyzed. So, patient holds the book between thumb and palm by using flexor pollicis longus (supplied by AIN nerve). A normal individual will be able to maintain a hold on the object without difficulty. With ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will experience difficulty maintaining a hold and this produces flexion at interphalangeal joint of the thumb, while holding book to maintain grip pressure causing a pinching effect. This is known as a positive froment’s sign.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Card test is done to evaluate the palmar interossei muscle paralysis or weakness due to ulnar nerve palsy.

choices.text: Extensor digitorum communis
Extensor digiti minimi

questions.text: Tendon used for repair of flexor tendon injury in hand requiring reconstruction from forearm to fingertip is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plantaris

 

Option B)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palmaris. The palmaris tendon is used for repair of flexor tendon injury from hand to the fingertip.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum communis. This muscle extends the forearm and the wrist. Thus, it is not used in flexor tendon injury repair.

 

Option D. Extensor digiti minimi. This muscle is responsible for 5th digit MCP joint extension. Thus, it is not used in flexor tendon injury repair.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The plantaris tendon is used for flexor tendon injury repair from the forearm to the fingertip.

questions.text: Crutch palsy is injury to which nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

Option A)

 

CRUTCH PALSY

 

  • Crutch palsy – Pressure palsy (radial nerve or part of brachial plexus injured)
  • Crutch paralysis is a type of paralysis that can occur when either the radial nerve or a part of the brachial plexus, which innervate sensory and motor function, is injured at the arm and hand, is below constant pressure, by the use of a crutch. 
  • This can conduct in paralysis of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve. 
  • Commonly, crutches that are not adjusted to the right height can cause the radial nerve to be constantly pushed against the humerus.
  • This can cause muscle innervated by the radial nerve to become partly/fully paralyzed.
  • This can lead to wrist drop, in which the fingers, hand, or wrist are in a flexed position because of paralysis of extensor muscles.
  • This condition normally improves quickly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve injury is related to the presence of claw hand deformity where there is flexion of the IP joint, hyperextension of the MCP joint due to paralysis of the lumbricals and the interossei.

 

Option C. Median nerve. If the median nerve is injured at the elbow, then there are pointing index and benediction hand deformities. This involves flexion of the IP joint of index and middle fingers. If the nerve is injured at the wrist, this may appear as the ape thumb deformity wherein the thumb is adducted and laterally rotated and lies in the same plane as other fingers, due to unopposed action of the extensor pollicis longus and adductor pollicis.
