Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Isolated injury to the musculocutaneous nerve cause weakness in elbow/shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and paraesthesia at the lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Crutch palsy is caused by the injury to the radial nerve due to pressure from the axillary pad of the crutch on the axilla.

choices.text: Superficial radial nerve
Posterior interosseous nerve palsy
High radial nerve palsy
Avulsion of triceps tendon

questions.text: Wrist Drop is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High radial nerve palsy

 

Option C)

 

WRIST DROP

 

  • High radial nerve palsy (RNP) results from damage to the trunk of the radial nerve, from where it emerges on the posterior cord of the brachial plexus to its division at the elbow.
  • High Radial Nerve Palsy characteristically presents as Wrist Drop, with sensory loss to the skin on the back of the hand, thumb, and fingers.
  • Brachioradialis is also affected.
  • A clinical examination confirms the lack of active extension in the wrist and finger metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints along with loss of thumb abduction.
  • Starting at 5-6 weeks, there is also visible atrophy of the muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superficial radial nerve. Injury to superficial radial nerve most commonly presents as loss of sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the hand including the back of the hand, the thumb and the index finger. There may be numbness or reduced sensitivity to touch, pain and temperature.

 

Option B. Posterior interosseous nerve palsy. Injury to posterior interosseous nerve most commonly leads to weakness or paralysis of the finger extensors leading to finger drop, leaving sensory functions intact.

 

Option D. Avulsion of triceps tendon. Avulsion of triceps tendon classically presents as pain and swelling at the back of the elbow or upper forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Wrist drop is a feature of high radial nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury is most commonly associated with a humerus shaft fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

Option A)

 

NERVE INJURIES AND THEIR ETIOLOGY

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Median nerve. The median nerve can be injured in the supracondylar humerus fracture.

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. An Axillary nerve is injured in the surgical neck of humerus fracture.

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve. It is injured in the fracture of the medial condyle of the humerus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • With humerus shaft fracture, there is an association of the radial nerve injury.

questions.text: Saturday night palsy involves which nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

Option A)

 

SATURDAY NIGHT PALSY

 

  • An object or surface pressing directly onto the upper medial arm or axilla for a prolonged period of time causes Saturday night palsy, a compressive neuropathy of the radial nerve. 
  • The classic scenario involves a person dozing off with their arm dangling over a chair or other hard surface, which causes compression in the axilla.

 

 

  • The onset of symptoms may take several days following the initial insult, resulting in a delayed presentation.
  • Numbness, weakness, tingling, pain, or any combination of these symptoms may be reported by patients.
  • Physical examination may reveal a characteristic wrist drop caused by the loss of extensor muscle function and the preservation of flexor muscle function.
  • As a result, the wrist and fingers cannot be extended at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The ability to extend the thumb is also lost, which makes it difficult to open the hand and grasp objects.
  • Sensory deficits commonly affect the posterior or lateral upper arm, with symptoms distributing distally to affect the posterior forearm, posterior hand, and posterolateral aspect of the lateral 3 ½ digits.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Median nerve. Common injuries to the median nerves include anterior shoulder dislocation, elbow dislocation, humerus fracture, midshaft radius fractures, stab wounds, and prolonged placement of a tourniquet.

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common cause of axillary nerve injury that can either compress the nerve or cause traction to it.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve is usually injured by brachial plexus damage, compression injury involving repeated elbow flexion and forearm supination like weightlifting, shoulder dislocation, or entrapment of the nerve at the elbow. It is not involved in Saturday night palsy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Saturday night palsy involves compression neuropathy of the radial nerve.

Ulnar nerve palsy
Median nerve palsy
Posterior interosseous nerve palsy

questions.text: Cock up splint is used in treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve palsy

 

Option A)

 

SPLINTS FOR NERVE INJURIES

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The cock-up splint is used for the radial nerve palsy to correct the wrist drop deformity of the hand.

choices.text: Loss of nerve supply to brachioradialis
Loss of nerve supply to extensor carpi radialis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about low Radial nerve palsy is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of nerve supply to brachioradialis

 

Option A)

 

LOW RADIAL NERVE PALSY

 

  • In low radial nerve palsy, the radial nerve is injured at the elbow.
  • This leads to sparing of the elbow and the wrist extension.
  • There is loss of thumb and finger extension.
  • Sensory loss occurs in the dorsum of the 1st web space of the hand.
  • In low radial nerve palsy, the brachioradialis muscle is spared.
  • Difference between high and low radial nerve palsies are:

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Following the low radial nerve palsy at the elbow, the brachioradialis muscle is spared.
  • There is loss of thumb and finger extension.
  • Sensory loss is present at the dorsum of the 1st web space of the hand.

choices.text: Injury to posterior interosseous nerve
Iatrogenic injury to common extensor origin
Injury to anterior interosseous nerve
High radial nerve palsy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male underwent excision of the right radial head. Following surgery, the patient developed an inability to extend the fingers and thumb of the right hand. He did not have any sensory deficit. Which one of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Injury to posterior interosseous nerve

 

Option A)

 

POSTERIOR INTEROSSEOUS NERVE INJURY

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, which comes off the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • With nerve roots C5 to T1, the radial nerve travels down the arm and divides into superficial and deep branches in the proximal forearm.  
  • Normally the deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve.  
  • Anatomical variants include the deep radial nerve passing through the Arcade of Frohse to become the posterior interosseous nerve.
  • This variant can increase susceptibility to impingement. 
  • Posterior Interosseous Nerve has close proximity to the radial neck.
  • The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm.
  • The terminal branch of the posterior interosseous nerve travels distally into the floor of the 4th dorsal compartment of the wrist to innervate the dorsal wrist capsule.
  • Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm.
  • It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension.
  • However, there should be preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus. 
  • It is often self-limiting and resolves with conservative measures.
  • Etiology:
    • Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can result from trauma, space-occupying lesions like rheumatoid arthritis, brachial neuritis, and spontaneous compression. 
    • The most common site of compression is at the arcade of Frohse (the proximal edge of the supinator).
    • Repetitive pronation/supination activities can also can posterior interosseous nerve syndrome.
    • Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be present in Monteggia fractures or radial head fracture-dislocations. 
    • Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be iatrogenic following reduction of radial fracture, transposition of the ulnar nerve or release of the extensor origin for lateral epicondylitis.
  • The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension.
  • Patients may have a history of vague proximal posterior forearm pain.
  • When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. 
  • Depending on injury severity, there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.
  • There will be no sensory loss as this nerve carries motor fibers only.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Iatrogenic injury to common extensor origin. The common extensor origin is a tendon attachment site for several muscles that extend the wrist and fingers. Injury to this area could lead to weakness or dysfunction in wrist and finger extension. However, in the scenario described in the question stem, the patient's inability to extend the fingers and thumb is more indicative of a specific nerve injury rather than a tendon injury.

 

Option C. Injury to anterior interosseous nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve primarily innervates the deep muscles of the forearm, such as the flexor pollicis longus, flexor digitorum profundus to the index finger, and pronator quadratus. Damage to this nerve typically results in weakness or paralysis of these specific muscles, leading to difficulty with pinch grip and loss of flexion at the distal interphalangeal joints of the thumb and index finger. The presentation described in the question, with inability to extend the fingers and thumb, does not align with the distribution of the anterior interosseous nerve.

 

Option D. High radial nerve palsy. High radial nerve palsy refers to a nerve injury occurring proximally along the radial nerve, usually at or above the level of the spiral groove of the humerus. This can result in weakness or paralysis of the triceps brachii, extensor muscles of the forearm, and wrist, finger, and thumb extension. However, the specific presentation described in the question stem (inability to extend the fingers and thumb) suggests a more localized nerve injury rather than a high radial nerve palsy, which would typically affect a broader distribution of muscles supplied by the radial nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve is injured commonly due to the radial head/neck fracture.
  • Since the presenting symptoms of the patient describes an inability to extend the fingers and the thumb without sensory deficit, it is suggestive of posterior interosseous nerve injury as this nerve is pure motor and do not have any sensory component.

choices.text: Spares nerve supply to extensor carpi radialis longus
Results in paralysis of anconeus muscle
Leaves extension at elbow joint intact
Weakens pronation movement

questions.text: Injury to radial nerve in lower part of spiral groove:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leaves extension at elbow joint intact

 

Option C)

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Triceps and anconeus are supplied by radial nerve above the level of spiral groove; so, these are spared in injuries of radial nerve at and below spiral groove thus, leaving elbow extension intact.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spares nerve supply to extensor carpi radialis longus. False. The extensor carpi radialis longus muscle is responsible for extending and abducting the wrist. However, in the radial nerve injury, there is loss of nerve supply to the extensor carpi radialis longus, leading to inability of wrist extension.

 

Option B. Results in paralysis of anconeus muscle. False. The anconeus muscle assists in extension of the elbow joint. Paralysis of this muscle would indeed affect the extension at the elbow joint. In the radial nerve injury at the spiral groove, anconeus muscle is spared. This, thus does not affect the extension of the elbow, along with the triceps muscle.

 

Option D. Weakens pronation movement. False. The radial nerve does not primarily control pronation; it primarily controls extension of the elbow, wrist, and fingers, and forearm supination. Injury to the radial nerve typically affects extension and supination movements rather than pronation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • If the extension at the elbow joint remains intact despite the injury, it implies that the radial nerve's function in supplying the triceps brachii responsible for elbow extension is preserved.

choices.text: Common Peroneal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury leads to Foot Drop
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Common Peroneal Nerve

 

Option A)

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is a major nerve that innervates the lower extremity.
  • It is one of the two major branches off the sciatic nerve. 
  • The common peroneal nerve separates from the sciatic nerve in the distal posterior thigh proximal to the popliteal fossa. 
  • After branching off of the sciatic nerve, it continues down the thigh, running posteroinferior to the biceps femoris muscle, and crosses laterally to the head of the lateral gastrocnemius muscle through the posterior intermuscular septum.
  • The nerve then curves around the fibular neck before dividing into two branches, the superficial peroneal nerve (SPN) and the deep peroneal nerve (DPN). 
  • The common peroneal nerve does not have any motor innervation before dividing; however, it provides sensory innervation to the lateral leg via the lateral sural nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. 
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve provides both motor and sensory innervation.
  • The common peroneal nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck. Therefore, it is most susceptible to injury at the lateral aspect of the knee.
  • The common etiologies of the common peroneal nerve injury are knee dislocation, and fibular neck fracture.
  • The injury to the nerve causes:
    • Paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, extensor hallucis longus and peroneus tertius (supplied by deep peroneal nerve) and peroneus longus and brevis (supplied by superficial peroneal nerve) – presenting as foot drop.
    • Loss of sensation down the anterior and lateral sides of leg and dorsum of foot and toes, including medial side of big toe.

 

 

 

  • Lateral border of foot and lateral side of little toe are unaffected (sural nerve mainly formed from tibial nerve).
  • The medial border of foot as far as the ball of big toe is completely unaffected (saphenous nerve, a branch of femoral nerve).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tibial nerve. Injury to the tibial nerve can cause motor loss, altered sensation and pain in the popliteal fossa region if it is injured due to a space-occupying lesion, laceration, posterior knee dislocation, or fracture of tibia and fibula. At the medial malleolus level, the nerve can get compressed in the tarsal tunnel, leading to tarsal tunnel syndrome, presenting as pain and paresthesia in sole of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve. Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon.

 

Option D. Obturator nerve. Obturator neuropathy may present as pain & paresthesia extending from hip to knee along the medial aspect of the thigh. Extension or lateral leg movement can increase pain. The patient may have trouble walking or experience leg weakness due to problems adducting the ipsilateral hip. There is weakness in the hip adductors on affected side, wasting of medial thigh, circumductory wide-based gait, sensory loss in the medial thigh, and ipsilateral loss of the hip adductor tendon reflex.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The foot drop deformity is caused by the injury to the common peroneal nerve.

questions.text:
Foot drop result because of injury to: 

 

  1. Superficial peroneal nerve
  2. Deep peroneal nerve
  3. Posterior tibial nerve
  4. Anterior tibial nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only 2 & 4

 

Option D)

 

FOOT DROP

 

  • Sciatic nerve has two components: tibial nerve (centrally arranged fibers) and common peroneal nerve (peripherally arranged fibers).
  • The injury to sciatic nerve sometimes can present as an injury only to common peroneal nerve because these fibers are peripheral and more prone to pressure.
  • Injury to the common peroneal nerve leads to weakness/paralysis of the foot dorsiflexors, leading to foot drop deformity.
  • Out of the superficial and deep branches of the common peroneal nerve, the deep peroneal nerve is the common cause of foot drop as the nerve supplies motor supply to the ankle and toe extensors.
  • The anterior tibial nerve, also called deep fibular nerve innervates the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and fibularis tertius muscles.
  • Injury to this nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of these muscles, leading to foot drop.

 

Explanation:

 

1. Superficial peroneal nerve. This nerve innervates the muscles that evert the foot and also provides sensation to the top of the foot and toes. Injury to this nerve would not typically result in foot drop.

 

3. Posterior tibial nerve. This nerve innervates the muscles that invert the foot and provide sensation to the sole of the foot. Injury to this nerve would not typically result in foot drop.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Both the deep peroneal nerve and the anterior tibial nerve gives motor supply to the muscles that dorsiflexes the foot.
  • Thus, any injury to these nerves leads to a classical foot drop deformity.

choices.text: Pregnancy is the most common cause
More common in women
Median nerve is compressed
Symptoms often appear at night

questions.text: All are true regarding carpal tunnel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pregnancy is the most common cause

 

Option A)

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Etiology:
  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders – Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, sarcoidosis.
  • Injury related – Synovitis of tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle’s fracture)

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Eight times more common in women than men.
    • The usual age group is 50 years.
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in the distribution of median nerve.
    • Pain is increased by activities, most troublesome in night and relieved by hanging the arm over the side of bed or shaking the arm.
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation.
    • In late cases, weakness of thumb abduction and wasting of thenar muscles occur.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The carpal tunnel syndrome is the compression of the median nerve at the wrist under the flexor retinaculum.
  • The most common cause is idiopathic, but can be due to other factors like hypothyroidism, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, traumatic tendon sheath synovitis, colles fracture etc.
  • It is 8 times more common in women than men of around 50 years of age.
  • The pain appears with activity but exaggerate at night, along with sensory symptoms, relieved by hanging the arm by the side of bed or shaking the arm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Menorrhagia

 

Option D)

 

ETIOLOGY OF CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders: Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, sarcoidosis.
  • Injury related: Synovitis of tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle’s fracture)

 

 

  • Menorrhagia is an abnormally heavy menstrual bleeding for more than 7 days.
  • There is no direct link between menorrhagia and carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome development is related to alcoholism, sarcoidosis and gout.
  • Menorrhagia or abnormal heavy bleeding is not related with development of carpal tunnel syndrome.
